2-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]]
2-door [[hardtop]] | platform = [[Chrysler A platform|A-body]] | layout = [[FR layout]] | related = [[Plymouth Valiant]]
[[Chrysler Valiant]] | successor = [[Dodge Dart#Third generation (1963–1966)|Dodge Dart]] | wheelbase = {{convert|106.5|in|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1961_Dodge/1961_Dodge_Lancer_Brochure/dirindex.html |title= 1961 Dodge Lancer Brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-23}} | length = {{convert|188.8|in|0|abbr=on}} }} For the 1961 [[model year]], Dodge applied the Lancer nameplate to its higher-priced, upmarket [[badge engineering|badge-engineered]] clone of Chrysler's very popular [[Plymouth Valiant|Valiant]] compact. The model was introduced when [[Chrysler]] officially assigned the [[Plymouth Valiant|Valiant]] to the [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]] division for 1961, leaving Dodge dealers without a compact to sell. All the same body variants available on the Valiant were also available on the Lancer: two- and four-door sedans, two-door hardtop and four-door wagons. At the end of 1962, it was renamed the [[Dodge Dart#Third generation (1963–1966)|Dodge Dart]]. In a survey of owners in the March, 1961 issue of [[Popular Mechanics]], 71.2% of owners liked that handling, but 12.3% thought that the workmanship was bad.{{cite news |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i98DAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=8 February 2020 |work=Popular Mechanics |date=March 1961}} ===Styling & trim=== [[File:1961 Dodge Lancer 770 Station Wagon (2).jpg|thumb|left|1961 Dodge Lancer 770 Station Wagon]] [[File:1962 Dodge Lancer 170 2-Door Sedan (rear).JPG|thumb|left|1962 Dodge Lancer 170 2-Door Sedan]] [[File:1962 Dodge Lancer GT 2-Door Hardtop.JPG|thumb|left|1962 Dodge Lancer GT 2-Door Hardtop]] The Lancer wheelbase and body shell were identical to those of the Valiant, but interior and exterior trim were more upscale for the Lancer. Lancers featured round [[Automotive lighting|taillights]] and a full-width grille, instead of the Valiant's cat's-eye taillights and central grille. For 1961, trim levels were the basic "170" and the premium "770". In 1961, the two-door hardtop was marketed only as the "Lancer 770 2-Door Hardtop". For 1962, the hardtop model was marketed as the "GT 2-Door Hardtop" and carried premium trim. Two-tone paint was available and instead of the front bench seat, there were two bucket seats. Also for the 1962 model, "Lancer GT" medallions were mounted on the doors' interior trim panels below the vent window and on the sides of the front fenders just aft of the [[headlamp]]s. "GT" emblems were placed on the hood, the deck lid and on the vinyl dash pad. The headlamp bezels and the grille's horizontal slats were blacked-out. The GT also lacked certain ornamentation found on the 170s and 770s such as the "Lancer" door scripts, the slanted chrome hash marks on the lower quarter panel, and the hook-ended [[stainless steel]] door-to-fender spears. ===Powertrains=== The Lancer used the [[Chrysler Slant 6 engine|slant-6]] engine. The base engine was the {{convert|170|cuin|l|1|abbr=on|adj=on}} unit, rated at {{convert|101|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. The optional power package consisted of the larger {{convert|225|cuin|l|1|abbr=on|adj=on}} engine, rated at {{convert|145|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. After the start of the 1961 model year, a [[die casting|die-cast]] [[aluminum]] version of the 225 engine block was made available. The aluminum 225 weighed {{convert|45|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} less than the iron 170 and {{convert|80|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} less than the iron 225. Any of the available engines could be equipped at the dealer with Chrysler's [[Chrysler Slant-6 engine#Hyper Pak|Hyper Pak]] parts kit for a significant power upgrade: the 170 Hyper Pak's published output was {{convert|148|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, while the 225 Hyper Pak's was {{convert|196|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. The Hyper-Pak shaved more than four seconds off the 0 to {{convert|60|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}} time versus the standard 225, and was over a second quicker and seven miles per hour faster in the quarter mile.{{cite book|last = Morris |first = Charles R. |title = Factory Lightweights: Detroit's Drag Racing Specials of the '60s |publisher = CarTech |year = 2007 |page = 17 |isbn = 978-1-932494-44-0}} With the Hyper Pak, a 225 Lancer could go from 0 to {{convert|60|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}} in 8.6 seconds and turn in a standing quarter mile time of 16.4 seconds.{{cite book|last = Young |first = Tony |title = Mighty Mopars 1960–1974 |publisher = Motorbooks International |year = 1984 |page = 25 |isbn = 978-0-87938-124-0}} 1962 cars had the engine and transmission moved for a flatter front floor.{{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1962_Dodge/1962_Dodge_Dart-Lancer_Brochure/1962%20Dodge%20Dart%20%20amp%20%20Lancer-10.html |title=Directory Index: Dodge/1962_Dodge/1962_Dodge_Dart-Lancer_Brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-23}} Transmission options were a Chrysler-built A903 three-speed manual with the shifter on the floor in 1961 and on the steering column in 1962, or a pushbutton-operated A904 [[Torqueflite]] three-speed automatic. ===Drag strip & sales competition=== In the 1962 [[NHRA]] Winternatonals, Wayne Weihe took home the win in the C/FX (Factory Experimental) class with his Hyper-Pak-equipped Lancer, clocking a 15.67 E.T. Although the bigger Dodges were beginning to appear at drag strips around the country, the "Golden Lancer" of Dode Martin and Jim Nelson was just about the fastest compact on the strips in 1962. Stuffed into the engine compartment was a {{convert|413|cuin|L||sp=us|abbr=in}} [[Chrysler RB engine#413|Chrysler RB V8]] engine modified by the Chrysler engineers' "Ramchargers" racing team. The Golden Lancer raced successfully in A/FX class and could do the quarter mile in 12.68 seconds at {{Convert|113|mph|0|abbr=on}}. Lancer sales did not meet expectations{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} and sold about half as well as the Valiant. As a late part of the total redesign of Dodge's compact car for 1963, the Lancer name was discontinued. Dodge compacts for 1963 through 1976 were named [[Dodge Dart|Dart]], a name that had previously been assigned to a larger car produced by Dodge from 1960 to 1962. ===South African market=== In [[South Africa]], a [[right hand drive]] version of the Lancer was sold from 1961 through 1963, badged as the '''DeSoto Rebel''' not long after the [[DeSoto (automobile)|DeSoto]] name was discontinued in the U.S. All Rebels were equipped with the {{convert|170|cuin|l|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler Slant 6 engine|Slant 6]] engine, and most were equipped with the three-speed manual transmission. As with the Australian [[Chrysler Valiant#R Series|RV1 and SV1]] Valiants, the Rebel used the instrument cluster from the U.S. 1961 [[Plymouth Valiant]]. White reflectors were mounted to the front bumper, in compliance with South African vehicle equipment regulations. The Rebel name was re-introduced by Chrysler South Africa in 1967 as the economy-priced "[[Chrysler Valiant|Valiant]] Rebel". {{-}} ==1985–1989 Lancer== {{Infobox automobile | name = 1985–1989 | image = 1988 dodge lancer es turbo.jpg | caption = 1988 Dodge Lancer ES Turbo | class = [[Mid-size car|Mid-size]] | production = August 1984–April 7, 1989 | assembly = [[Sterling Heights, Michigan]], [[United States]] | engine = {{convert|2.2|l|cuin|0|abbr=on|adj=on}} ''[[Chrysler K engine#2.2|K]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]]

{{convert|2.2|l|cuin|0|abbr=on|adj=on}} ''[[Chrysler K engine#2.2 Turbo II|Turbo II]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]]
{{convert|2.5|l|cuin|0|abbr=on|adj=on}} ''[[Chrysler K engine#2.5|K]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]] | transmission = 5-speed manual
3-speed ''[[Torqueflite#A413|A413]]'' automatic | body_style = 5-door [[hatchback]] | platform = [[Chrysler H platform|H-body]] |layout=[[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|Transverse front-engine, front-wheel drive]] | related = [[Chrysler LeBaron GTS]]
[[Chrysler LeBaron]]
Chrysler GTS (Europe)
[[Shelby Lancer]] }} The Dodge Lancer was re-introduced in 1985 as a mid-sized 5-door [[hatchback]]. It was a rebadged version of the more expensive [[Chrysler LeBaron|Chrysler LeBaron GTS]] and was based on the [[Chrysler H platform]], a stretched version of the [[Chrysler K platform]]. The Lancer eventually slotted between the [[Dodge Aries|Aries]] and the [[Dodge 600|600]]. All Lancers were built in [[Sterling Heights, Michigan|Sterling Heights]], [[Michigan]]. Production ended on April 7, 1989, replaced by the [[Dodge Spirit|Spirit]]. ===Lancer Shelby=== The 1988 to 1989 "Lancer Shelby" was a factory appearance and handling package including upgraded [[sway bar]]s, shorter springs, and quicker steering along with an assortment of comfort and convenience features including leather seats, power locks, windows, seats and mirrors, a tilt steering wheel and a two-position cup holder.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} It was inspired by the 1987 [[Shelby Lancer]], which was built by [[Carroll Shelby#Shelby Dodges and Dodge Shelbys|Shelby Automobiles]] in Whittier, California. Chrysler took over production starting with the 1988 model year, building them in the same Sterling Heights plant as regular Lancers. The [[intercooled]] [[Chrysler K engine#2.2 Turbo II|Turbo II]] engine with the [[manual transmission]] provided {{convert|175|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. The [[automatic transmission|automatic]] variant was equipped with the {{convert|146|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler K engine#2.2 Turbo I|Turbo I]]{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}}. Although it was not planned as a limited edition, only 279 Lancer Shelbys were produced in 1988 and 208 in 1989{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}}. ===European market=== In April 1988, Chrysler started offering some models on the European market. One of them was the "Chrysler GTS", a rebadged version of the Dodge Lancer ES. Due to [[ECE Regulations|European vehicle regulations]], the exterior appearance was slightly different. The rear [[Automotive lighting#Turn signal colour|turn signals]] were amber rather than red, the front [[Automotive lighting#Sidemarker lights and reflectors|sidemarkers]] and the [[Automotive lighting#Centre High Mount Stop Lamp|centre high mount stop lamp]] (CHMSL) were blanked off, small round [[Automotive lighting#Side turn signals|repeaters]] were installed into the front fenders and the [[Wing mirror|sideview mirrors]] were of spring-hinged rather than rigid design. The engine options included the naturally aspirated {{convert|2.2|l|cuin|0||abbr=on|adj=on}} Four, and a turbocharged version of the same engine. From 1989 on, the {{convert|2.5|l|cuin|0|abbr=on|adj=on}} Four became available with or without a turbocharger. The 2.2 engine was dropped, except for the Turbo II version that was standard equipment on the Chrysler GTS Shelby, the European sibling of the [[Dodge Lancer#Lancer Shelby|Dodge Lancer Shelby]]. A five-speed manual gearbox was standard, with a three-speed automatic transmission as an extra cost option. The GTS Shelby came only with the manual transmission. The Chrysler GTS had few buyers in Europe; the competition was too hard. Even the comparatively low prices could not help, and sales figures were very low. By the end of 1989, the GTS was replaced by the [[Chrysler Saratoga#1989–1995|Saratoga]]. {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.imcdb.org/vehicles.php?make=Dodge&model=Lancer IMCDB: Dodge Lancers in movies & TV shows] {{Commons category}} {{Dodge}} {{Dodge early timeline}} {{Dodge timeline 1950–1979}} {{Dodge timeline 1980 to date}} {{Dodge Timeline}} {{Dodge Canada Timeline}} {{Dodge Mexico Timeline}} [[Category:Dodge vehicles|Lancer]] [[Category:Compact cars]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Mid-size cars]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Coupés]] [[Category:Hatchbacks]] [[Category:Sedans]] [[Category:Station wagons]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1955]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1961]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1985]]

[[Plymouth Caravelle]] |wheelbase = {{convert|103.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length = {{convert|185.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |layout = [[FF layout]] |width = {{convert|68.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|53.1|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} The '''Dodge 600''' is a [[mid-size car]] that was built by [[Dodge]]. It was introduced in 1982, as a 1983 model, based on the [[Chrysler E platform]] and was discontinued after the 1988 model year. It was [[Chrysler]]'s answer to the [[GM A platform (FWD)|GM A-body]], whereas the [[Chrysler M platform|M-body]] [[Dodge Diplomat]] would compete with [[full-size car]]s. It replaced the [[Dodge 400|400]]. (Dodge 600 coupes and convertibles were, essentially, rebadged 400s.) Like the preceding 400, it was positioned between the [[Dodge Aries|Aries]] and [[Dodge Diplomat|Diplomat]]. ==Debut== The 600 was intended to be Dodge's answer to the European sedans of the day. Its numerical name and rear-end styling was designed to evoke thoughts of [[Mercedes-Benz]] models, however it fell more in line with North American contemporaries such as the [[Chevrolet Celebrity]], [[Pontiac 6000]] and the [[Ford Fairmont]] (the 600 actually resembled the [[Dodge Mirada]] more than any [[Europe]]an car). It debuted as a four-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]], available in two trims: Base and ES ("Euro Sport"). Power was provided by Chrysler's 2.2 L 4-cylinder engine, with the Mitsubishi-built 2.6 L [[Inline-four engine|4-cylinder]] available as an option. File:Dodge 600 coupe.jpg|1984–1985 Dodge 600 coupe File:'86-'87 Dodge 600 Convertible.jpg|1986 Dodge 600 convertible File:1988600.jpg|1988 Dodge 600 sedan File:1986-88 Dodge 600 SE rear.jpg|Rear of 1986-1988 600 SE sedan Sales of the 600 nearly doubled in its second year. This was in large part due to the addition of the former [[Dodge 400|400's]] coupe and convertible body styles to the 600's range (which continued to stay on the [[Chrysler K platform|K platform]]). Like most midrange-to-upscale K-car derivatives, digital dashboards and the [[Electronic Voice Alert]] were options. ==ES Turbo== Mid-way into 1984 Dodge introduced a sporty new "ES Turbo" package for convertibles. It featured Chrysler's new 2.2 L {{convert|142|hp|kW|abbr=on}} Turbocharged engine (which also became an option on sedans and coupes) and a special sport-tuned "ES" suspension. The interior came with standard leather seats, digital dashboard, and four-spoke steering wheel (redesigned in 1985). Visual exterior cues differentiate ES models from base convertibles by way of blacked-out trim (replacing much of the chrome), 15-inch "pizza" style aluminum wheels, "ES" decklid badges, Turbo fender badges, and functioning dual hood vents. Sales of the ES Turbo were initially slow, with only 1786 copies being sold for the 1984 model year. Output increased to 5621 for 1985, then eased to 4759 for 1986, after which the model was discontinued along with all 600 convertibles. Base price for the 1986 ES Turbo convertible was $14,856. ==Midlife changes== Several changes were made to the 600 in 1985. The 600 [[Sedan (car)|sedan]] was moved to a longer wheelbase and the former base and ES trims were dropped, replaced by a new SE trim. This was due in part to the new [[Dodge Lancer#1980s|Lancer]], which would have competed directly with the 600 (the 5-speed [[manual transmission]] was no longer offered as well, in an attempt to keep competition between the [[Dodge Lancer#1980s|Lancer]] and 600 to a minimum). The [[coupe]] and [[convertible (car)|convertible]] remained relatively unchanged except for minor trim and interior changes. The only significant advancement was the replacement of the 2.2 L engine's two-barrel Holley electronic feedback [[carburetor]] by an electronic throttle-body [[fuel injection]] system. The sedan's base trim returned in 1986, while all 600s were given new, restyled front and rear fascias (the front in particular adopted the now familiar "crosshair" grille, dropping the [[Dodge Mirada|Mirada]]-inspired horizontal slats). The 2.6 L engine was replaced by a modified [[Chrysler K engine#2.5|2.5 L]] version of the Chrysler 2.2 L. ==End of production== The phase out of the 600 started in 1987 with the coupe and convertible versions being discontinued in that year. Production of the sedan ended in 1988. The 600 was replaced by the 1988 [[Dodge Dynasty]] (badged as a [[Chrysler (division)|Chrysler]] in Canada, whereas the Canadian successor is the [[Dodge Spirit]]). There were negotiations to build the car in China after production ended. [[Hongqi (marque)|Hongqi]] imported a couple of 600s and applied a new rear end and Hongqi badging, intending to sell them as the Hongqi CA750F in China. However, Volkswagen's long-term outlook convinced the Chinese otherwise and Hongqi chose to build the [[Audi 100]] instead, albeit fitted with a locally built version of Chrysler's 2.2-liter inline-four. ==Sales== {|class= "wikitable" | style="float:left;" border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" !colspan="2" | Production |- !style="background:#C0C0C0;" | Model Year !style="background:#C0C0C0;" | Units |- !align="centered"| 1983 || 33,488 |- !align="centered"| 1984 || 61,637 |- !align="centered"| 1985 || 58,847 |- !align="centered"| 1986 || 59,677 |- !align="centered"| 1987 || 40,391 |- !align="centered"| 1988 || 55,550 |- !style="background:#C0C0C0;" | Total !style="background:#C0C0C0;" | 309,590 |} {{commons category}} {{Dodge}} {{Dodge timeline 1980 to date}} {{Dodge Timeline}} {{Dodge Canada Timeline}} [[Category:Dodge vehicles|600]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Mid-size cars]] [[Category:Coupés]] [[Category:Convertibles]] [[Category:Sedans]] [[Category:1980s cars]]

1989–1990: {{convert|67.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|53.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} The '''Dodge Spirit''' is a mid-size 5- or 6-passenger sedan that was introduced in January 1989 as a replacement for the similarly sized [[Dodge 600]].{{cite book| title=Chrysler Corporation Master Technician Service Conference book |chapter=New Model Service Highlights '89 |page=4 |quote=Spirit and Acclaim are the new midsize sedans, replacing 600 and Caravelle.| publisher=Chrysler Corporation }} The Spirit was [[Dodge]]'s version of the [[Chrysler A platform|Chrysler AA platform]], a stretched variation of the [[Chrysler K platform]]. It was assembled at [[Newark Assembly]] in [[Newark, Delaware]], [[Toluca Car Assembly]] in [[Toluca]], [[Mexico]], as well as [[Valencia]], [[Venezuela]], and shared its basic design with the 1990 to 1994 [[Chrysler LeBaron]] sedan, the 1989 to 1995 [[Plymouth Acclaim]], and the export-only 1989 to 1995 [[Chrysler Saratoga#1989–1995|Chrysler Saratoga]]. The Spirit has also been described as a replacement for the smaller [[Dodge Aries|Aries]] and the hatchback [[Dodge Lancer#1980s|Lancer]], though the [[Dodge Shadow|Shadow]] launched in 1986 is closer than the Spirit in most dimensions to the Aries and Lancer.{{cite book|title=Standard Catalog of Chrysler 1924-1990 |first=John |last=Lee |year=1990 |publisher= Krause Publications |isbn=978-0-87341-142-4 |page=338 }}{{cite web|first=Aaron |last=Gold |first2=Michael |last2=Swern |title=Kronology: History of the K-car |url= http://www.allpar.com/eek/k/kron.html |accessdate=22 July 2013 }}{{cite web |title=1990-1995 Dodge Spirit: Full Review |publisher=Consumer Guide |url=http://consumerguideauto.howstuffworks.com/1990-to-1995-dodge-spirit-6.htm |date=13 November 2010 |accessdate=22 July 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121203113329/http://consumerguideauto.howstuffworks.com/1990-to-1995-dodge-spirit-6.htm |archivedate=3 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }} A total of 60,000 Dodge Spirits were sold in its first year{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}}, enough that Aries production was stopped mid-season. Spirit production ended on December 9, 1994, along with the [[Plymouth Acclaim]] and it was marketed through 1995. The "[[Cab forward#Road vehicles|cab-forward]]" [[Dodge Stratus|Stratus]] was introduced as a replacement. == Design == The Spirit could accommodate six people with an optional front split-bench seat. It had a large trunk, a solid-beam rear axle, and a [[MacPherson strut]] front suspension. The Spirit differed from the other A-bodies primarily in the grille and [[automotive lighting|rear lamp]] styling, and in the availability of a sportier, higher-performing R/T version. The Spirit is dimensionally comparable to its contemporaneous [[Ford Tempo]], and was also compared with the [[Ford Taurus]], [[Honda Accord]], and [[Toyota Camry]] by Consumer Reports{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}}. The Spirit sold well; with higher consumer acceptance than the [[Dodge Stratus|Stratus]] that replaced it.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} ==Changes through the years== [[File:Dodge Spirit RT.jpg|thumb|right|1992 Dodge Spirit R/T]] [[File:Dodge Spirit .jpg|thumb|right|1993–1995 Dodge Spirit]] * 1991 - Antilock four-wheel disk brake system was added as a new option. * 1992 - A 3-speed automatic transmission became available with the V6 engine. * 1993 - A facelift included a body-color grille with the Dodge crossbars theme and new full-width [[automotive lighting|taillamps]] that despite their amber lower sections, did not include amber rear [[Automotive lighting#Turn signal colour|turn signals]]. Only two trim levels went on sale: Highline and ES. The Chrysler corporate pentastar emblem was replaced with the brand's new RAM emblem. Stainless steel exhaust system and tinted glass became standard on all Spirits. * 1994 - A motorized passenger's side [[seat belt]] was added to [[United States|U.S.]]-market Spirits to comply with [[FMVSS|Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 208]]'s requirement for passive restraints. These motorized belts do not comply with [[Canada]]'s safety standards; Canadian-market Spirits continued to use a manual passenger seatbelt, and 1994–1995 Spirits therefore cannot legally be permanently imported across the US/Canada border in either direction.{{cite web|url=http://www.riv.ca/english/html/how_to_import.html |title=Canadian vehicle importation regulations |publisher=Riv.ca |date=|accessdate=22 July 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.nhtsa.dot.gov/cars/rules/import/FMVSS/#SN101 |title=US vehicle importation regulations|publisher=Nhtsa.dot.gov |date=December 1998 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }} * 1995 - The 2.5 L engine received a slightly revised cylinder head, and both the 4-speed A604 [[automatic transmission]] and [[anti-lock brakes]] were dropped from the option list. Otherwise, the Spirit remained mostly unchanged, much as it had throughout its six-year run. ==Trims== * 1989–95: Base * 1989–91: LE * 1989–93: ES * 1991–92: R/T The Spirit ES and R/T featured ''Eurocast'' (also called ''Snowflake'') alloy wheels through 1991. For 1992, the ''Turbo Blade'' wheel was introduced.{{cite web|url= http://www.dempseybowling.com/shelby/wheel101.htm |title=A primer for Shelby/Dodge FWD wheels |publisher=Dempseybowling.com |date=4 July 2001 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110709011936/http://www.dempseybowling.com/shelby/wheel101.htm |archivedate=9 July 2011 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }} Some of the alloy wheels were color-keyed to the vehicle body: *White body with white painted wheels (ES, R/T) *Black, silver, or dark red body with clear-coated wheels (ES only) *Bright Red body with bright red painted wheel inserts (R/T only, 1991) Starting in 1993, the Spirit was offered with a ''Gold'' package similar to that offered on the 1993-94 [[Plymouth Acclaim]] and [[Dodge Caravan]]/[[Plymouth Voyager]] minivans. This included goldtone-trimmed alloy wheels and gold pinstripes. The Gold package was available with both 4- and 6-cylinder models, with certain body colors. ==Engines== The base engine for Spirit and Spirit LE models was a {{convert|2.5|L|cuin|abbr=on}} [[Fuel injection#Throttle body injection|TBI]] [[Chrysler K engine|4-cylinder engine]] producing {{convert|100|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}}. Optional on all models except the Spirit R/T was a {{convert|141|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}}, [[Mitsubishi 6G7 engine#6G72|{{convert|3.0|L|cuin|abbr=on}} L V6]] made by [[Mitsubishi Motors|Mitsubishi]]. Also available in 1989 through 1992—and standard equipment on the Spirit ES—was a {{convert|150|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} [[turbocharged]] version of the 2.5 L engine. In 1993, 1994, and 1995, a [[flexible fuel vehicle|flexible-fuel]] Spirit was offered, powered by a {{convert|107|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} [[MPFI|multipoint fuel injected]] version of the 2.5 L engine specially modified to run on fuel containing up to 85% [[methanol]]. The R/T version came with a powerful {{convert|135|cuin|L|1|disp=flip|abbr=on}} [[DOHC]] turbo III with cylinder head engineered and made by [[Lotus (car)|Lotus]]. This engine was rated at {{convert|224|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|217|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}}. ==Transmissions== Several five-speed [[manual transmission]]s were available with the naturally aspirated and turbocharged 4-cylinder engines, but relatively few Spirits were equipped with manual transmissions. All the Spirit R/Ts came with the A-568 heavy-duty 5-speed manual transmission. From 1989 to 1991, all V6 Spirits came with the electronic four-speed [[ultradrive|A604]] overdrive automatic, which became optional equipment in 1992 and remained optional until 1995. The three-speed [[TorqueFlite#A413|Torqueflite]] automatic was the most popular installation on 4-cylinder Spirits, and was also standard equipment with the V6 engine from 1992 through 1995. A 5-speed manual was offered with the V6 engine in the smaller [[Dodge Shadow|Shadow]], but this combination was not available in the Spirit. ==R/T== [[File:Spirit RT Interior.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Dodge Spirit R/T interior]] [[File:Spirit RT Front34.jpg|thumb|left|1991 Dodge Spirit R/T at the [[Road America]] [[racetrack]]]] [[File:Spirit RT Engine.jpg|thumb|left|1991 Dodge Spirit R/T engine bay]] In 1991, Chrysler introduced the '''Spirit R/T''', featuring a version of the 2.2 L engine with a [[multi-valve|16-valve]] [[DOHC]] head designed by [[Lotus (car)|Lotus]], who won a design competition against Maserati and Hans Hermann. Fed by a [[Garrett AiResearch|Garrett]] [[intercooled]] [[turbocharger]], the ''[[Chrysler K engine#2.2 Turbo III|Turbo III]]'' engine produced {{convert|224|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|217|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}}. The R/T also featured unique interior and exterior trims. The only transmission was a heavy-duty A568 5-speed [[manual transmission]] built by Chrysler's New Process Gear division, with a gearset supplied by [[Getrag]]. Heavy-duty vented four wheel disc brakes were standard equipment, with optional [[anti-lock brakes]]. Color-keyed 15-inch alloy wheels were standard, with P205/60R15 tires. At the time, the R/T was advertised as "the fastest sedan made in America", and one of the quickest performance sedans under $40,000, with Chrysler placing its performance above the [[BMW M5]]. It could reach {{convert|60|mph|km/h|0|abbr=on}} in 5.8 seconds, according to ''[[Car and Driver]]'', making it one of the quickest [[front wheel drive]] cars ever offered in the American market. It was chosen as ''[[Motor Trend]]'' magazine's "Domestic Sport Sedan of the Year", beating the [[Ford Taurus SHO]] for 1991 and 1992. All R/Ts were built in Mexico. A total of 1,208 were sold in the U.S. in 1991 — 774 in red and 434 in white. An additional 191 were sold in the U.S. in 1992 — 92 red, 68 white, and 31 silver. The only discernible changes for 1992 were a lower first gear ratio for reduced [[Turbocharger#Lag|turbo lag]], woodgrain dashboard trim as used on the [[Chrysler LeBaron]] sedan, blacked out upper and lower grille inserts, clear rather than amber lenses for the front parking and turn signal lights, and a [[speedometer]] calibrated to {{convert|150|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} rather than {{convert|120|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. {{clear}} ==Mexican and South American markets== [[File:94RT 1.jpg|thumb|left|Mexican 1994 Chrysler Spirit R/T]] [[File:2.5 litre carburetted K engine (1990 Chrysler Spirit).jpg|thumb|right|[[Carburetor|Carbureted]] 2.5 L engine installed in 1990 Mexican Chrysler Spirit]] [[File:25EFI.jpg|thumb|right|[[Fuel injection|MPFI]] 2.5 L engine installed in 1994 Mexican Chrysler Spirit]] Spirits were marketed in [[Cars in Mexico|Mexico]]. They were badged as Chryslers rather than Dodges, since the Dodge brand at the time was used only on trucks. The Spirit was introduced in the Mexican market for 1990, one year after its début in the U.S. and Canada. The 1990-1991 Mexican versions were equipped with the U.S. market Plymouth Acclaim tail lights. The initial 1990-model Spirits used a version of the 2.5 L engine operating on [[Gasoline#Lead|leaded gasoline]], equipped with a [[carburetor]], a tubular exhaust [[Exhaust manifold|header]], and electronic control of ignition timing.{{cite web|url=http://u225.torque.net/cars/mexpirit.html |title=1992 Chrysler Spirit (built in Mexico) |publisher=U225.torque.net |date= |accessdate=2011-09-23}} This induction and ignition system used technology and components very similar to those employed in Chrysler's U.S.-market [[Lean burn#Chrysler Lean Burn computer|Lean Burn]] emission control systems of the late-1970s. For the 1991 [[model year]], Mexico enacted new-vehicle [[Automobile emissions control|emission]] regulations similar to those in the U.S. and Canada. The carbureted leaded-fuel engine was too dirty to comply with the new regulations, so a fully integrated engine management system with [[fuel injection]] was added to the Spirit. This was not the [[Fuel injection#Throttle body injection|TBI]] system used in the U.S., Canada, and [[Europe]]. Rather, the Mexican-market Spirits came with a more advanced [[MPFI]] setup. The MPFI 2.5 improved performance and driveability, as well as achieved cleaner emissions than its TBI counterpart, but was not used in the U.S., Canadian, or rest-of-world export markets except on turbocharged and FFV models. The Chrysler Spirit with MPFI 2.5 L engine was sold in Mexico from 1991 through 1995, and was exported to [[Argentina]] and [[Brazil]] from 1993 through 1995. It was employed by the [[Argentine]] police in [[Buenos Aires]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} [[File:ChryslerSpiritPFA.jpg|thumb|Chrysler Spirit, police car in Argentina]] Chrysler de Mexico also sold two versions of the Spirit R/T. The base R/T, sold from 1991 through 1995, used a Mexico-only {{convert|168|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} intercooled Turbo II version of the 8-valve [[SOHC]] 2.5 L engine and the 3-speed [[Torqueflite#A413|A413]] automatic transmission. These R/Ts were used by Mexican [[police]] departments. The top-line R/T. called "R/T DOHC", available from 1992 through 1993, came with the same 2.2 L 16-valve [[DOHC]] engine that was used in the American-market in the 1991 to 1992 R/T with a 5-speed manual transmission. More options and higher equipment levels were available in Mexico, including leather upholstery, sunroof, and 16-inch alloy wheels, none of which was offered on the R/T in America. In addition, Mexican-market R/Ts could be ordered in a variety of different colors, not just the red, white, and silver offered in the U.S. All Mexican-market Spirit R/Ts were badged as Chryslers. A variant of the R/T family, the [[Chrysler Phantom R/T]], was a special-order Mexico-only premium version of the [[Chrysler LeBaron|LeBaron]] coupe equipped with the 2.2 L 16-valve DOHC engine and the ''Getrag'' 5-speed manual transmission. {{clear}} ===Sales=== {|class="wikitable" |- ! {{See also|1955 Dodge}}{{More citations needed|date=February 2019}}{{Infobox automobile | image = DodgeLaFemme.jpg | caption = 1955 Dodge La Femme | name = Dodge La Femme | manufacturer = [[Dodge]] ([[Chrysler]]) | production = 1955–1956 | assembly = [[Dodge Main|Dodge Main Factory]], [[Hamtramck, MI]], United States | related = [[DeSoto Custom]] | class = [[Full-size]] | body_style = 2-door [[hardtop]] | layout = [[FR layout]] | engine = [[V8 engine|V8]] | transmission = | length = {{convert|212|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = | height = | wheelbase = {{convert|120|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | weight = | aka = [[Dodge Custom Royal Lancer]] | designer= }}
[[File:1956 Dodge La Femme rear.jpg|thumb|right|1956 Dodge La Femme]] [[File:1956 Dodge La Femme interior.jpg|thumb|right|1956 La Femme interior]] [[File:1956 Dodge La Femme fenderF.jpg|thumb|right|Gold-colored "La Femme" fender script]]
The '''Dodge La Femme''' is a [[full-size]]d [[automobile]] that was produced by [[Dodge]] between 1955 and 1956. The automobile was specifically designed for women.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xdwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA133&dq=1954+Popular+Mechanics+January |title=Dodge's LaFemme Is First Automobile With A Gender |journal=Popular Mechanics |volume=104 |issue=1 |date=July 1955 |page=133 |accessdate=28 February 2012 }}</ref>
== Origin == The La Femme's reason for becoming a car was stemmed from Chrysler's marketing department's observation that more and more women were taking an interest in automobiles during the 1950s, and that women’s opinions on which color car to buy was becoming part of the decision making process for couples buying an automobile. The La Femme was an attempt to gain a foothold in the women's automobile market.
The La Femme concept was based upon two Chrysler show cars from the 1954 season. Named '''Le Comte''', and '''La Comtesse''', each was built from a [[Chrysler Newport]] hardtop body, and each was given a clear plastic roof over the entire passenger compartment. While the Le Comte was designed using masculine colors, the La Comtesse was painted "Dusty Rose" and "Pigeon Grey" in order to convey femininity. Favorable responses encouraged Chrysler to pursue the La Comtesse concept.
== 1955 == Dodge received the project and renamed the concept the '''La Femme''', which began as a 1955 [[Dodge Lancer|Dodge Custom Royal Lancer]] "spring special" hardtop two-door coupe, painted "Sapphire White" and "Heather Rose". From there, the exterior received special gold-colored "La Femme" scripts that replaced the standard "Custom Royal Lancer" scripts on the cars front fenders.
The interior of the car also received attention and features. 1955 La Femme interiors were upholstered in a special [[tapestry]] material featuring pink rosebuds on a pale silver-pink background and pale pink vinyl trim. The La Femme came with a keystone-shaped, pink calfskin purse that coordinated with the interior of the car. The purse could be stowed in a compartment in the back of the passenger seat,<ref>{{cite book|last=Flory, Jr.|first=J. "Kelly"|title=American Cars, 1946-1959 Every Model Every Year|year=2008|publisher=McFarland |isbn=978-0-7864-3229-5}}</ref> and its gold-plated medallion faced outward. This [[brushed-metal]] medallion was large enough to have the owner's name engraved on it.
Each purse was outfitted with a coordinated set of accessories inside, which included a face-powder compact, lipstick case, cigarette case, comb, cigarette lighter and change purse, all made of either faux-tortoiseshell plastic and gold-tone metal, or pink calfskin and gold-tone metal, and all were designed and made by “Evans”, a maker of women's fine garments and accessories in Chicago.
On the back of the drivers seat was a compartment that contained a raincoat, rain bonnet and umbrella,<ref name="Ahrens">{{cite web|last1=Ahrens|first1=Ronald|title=Dodge La Femme: Rhapsody in Pink|url=http://www.jeanknowscars.com/car-life/style/dodge-la-femme/|website=www.jeanknowscars.com|accessdate=19 April 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506045338/http://www.jeanknowscars.com/car-life/style/dodge-la-femme/|archivedate=6 May 2016}}</ref> all made from a vinyl patterned to match the rosebud interior fabric. Marketing brochures stated that the car was made ''"By Special Appointment to Her Majesty... the American Woman."''
== 1956 == For 1956, the La Femme returned, with no less fanfare; letters to dealers from Dodge’s marketing department called the La Femme a "stunning success". For 1956, Dodge replaced the Heather Rose and Sapphire White scheme with a Misty Orchid and Regal Orchid color scheme. The interior of the car in 1956 did not take its cue from the 1955 model, and instead featured "La Femme"-only seat patterns, headliner, interior paint and carpet. The fabrics used have proven difficult to reproduce. The seat coverings were made of a heavy white cloth with random, organic-seeming patterns of short lavender and purple loops, in a manner similar to loop-pile carpeting. The headliner cloth was heavy white fabric, with many tiny random splashes of gold paint. The carpeting was loop pile with several shades of lavender and purple. The boxes behind the seats were changed for 1956 to accommodate the rain coat, rain cap and umbrella provided with the model. Both boxes were identical this year, because there was no need to accommodate a purse, which was only offered with the 1955 La Femme.
== Legacy == Dodge dropped the La Femme for 1957 and did not revisit the concept. Because the La Femme was an option package ($143), its total production was never broken out from Dodge's production numbers, although research suggests fewer than 2,500 were made over the two-year period. At least 40 known examples exist of the 1955 version and over 20 for the 1956 version, including at least 3 verifiable [[Chrysler B engine|Dodge D-500 engine]] optioned 1956 La Femme.{{Citation needed|reason=Reference the production and still "existing" figures|date=October 2019}}
Many theories exist concerning the low sales of the La Femme trim package. No evidence of magazine, television, radio, or other La Femme advertisements have been found since 1986. Given the large number of Dodge dealerships in the U.S. at the time, few of them received a demonstration La Femme for their showroom. Entitled “By Special Appointment to Her Majesty... the American Woman" dealer three-fold single-sheet pamphlets promoted the car as "in mood and manner" for a "discriminating. modern woman."<ref>{{cite web |last=Kelly |first=Erin |title=You Won't Believe The "Woman's Car" Dodge Made In 1955 |url= https://allthatsinteresting.com/dodge-la-femme |website=All That's Interesting |accessdate=6 October 2019 |date=1 July 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Howell |first=Justina |title=The Pink Car for Women in the 1950s |url= https://www.thevintagenews.com/2019/03/31/dodge-la-femme/ |website=The Vintage News |accessdate=6 October 2019 |date=31 March 2019}}</ref> Other trim-special models such as the [[Chrysler 300 letter series]], [[Plymouth Fury]], and [[DeSoto Adventurer]] were widely promoted.
== Sources == *{{cite journal |title=LaFemme: a fancy and feminine statement of the chauvinist '50s |journal=Aftermarket Business |first=James |last=Guyette |date=January 2004 }} *{{cite journal |title=1955-56 Dodge La Femme: "By Appointment to Her Majesty – the American Woman" |journal=Collectible Automobile |first=Tony |last=Lindsey |date=February 1988 }}

[[Kenosha, Wisconsin]] (1985–1988) |wheelbase = {{convert|99.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web |title=1978 Dodge Omni brochure |url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/new/171110/1978%20Dodge%20Omni/1978%20Dodge%20Omni-11.html |website=oldcarbrochures.com |date=December 1977|accessdate=16 November 2019}} |length = {{convert|163.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|66.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|53.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |weight = {{convert|2137|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} }} The '''Dodge Omni''' and '''Plymouth Horizon''' are [[subcompact]] cars that were produced by [[Chrysler]] from 1977 to 1990.{{cite book |title=Quattroruote: Tutte le Auto del Mondo 1985 |editor= Mastrostefano, Raffaele |publisher=Editoriale Domus |ref=TAM85 |year=1985 |page=249 |language=Italian |location=Milano |isbn=88-7212-012-8}} The Omni and Horizon were reengineered variants of the European [[Chrysler Horizon]] and became the first front-wheel-drive economy cars to be built in the US.{{cite web |title=The Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon |url= https://www.allpar.com/omni/omni.html |publisher=Allpar |accessdate=16 November 2019}} Marketed for eleven years with very few changes, around 2,500,000 Omnis and Horizons were built with the Plymouth badged versions more popular than the Dodge branded models. These were the first of many front-wheel drive Chrysler products to follow, including the [[Plymouth Reliant|Dodge Aries/Plymouth Reliant]] and the initial [[Chrysler minivans]]. ==History== {{see also|Simca-Talbot Horizon}} The Dodge Omni and the Plymouth Horizon were [[front-wheel drive]], five-door hatchbacks, introduced by the [[Dodge]] and [[Plymouth automobile|Plymouth]] divisions of [[Chrysler]] in [[North America]] in January 1978. The Omni and Horizon were the first front-wheel drive cars produced by Chrysler, and among the first American front-wheel drive cars to sell in large numbers (previous front-wheel drive American cars such as the [[Cord (automobile)|Cord 810]], [[Cadillac Eldorado]], and [[Oldsmobile Toronado]] were low-volume luxury cars). [[File:Simca Chrysler Horizon GLS 1979.jpg|left|thumb|Chrysler Horizon]] The Omni and Horizon were developed in parallel with the [[Simca Horizon|Horizon]], a [[subcompact]] car designed by [[Simca]], the [[France|French]] division of [[Chrysler Europe]], and built on the then-new [[Chrysler L platform|L platform]]. This was Chrysler's first and last attempt at a 'world car'. The Simca Horizon survived in various guises under the successor Talbot name until 1987. Born largely out of the need to replace the aging [[Simca 1100]], the Horizon was essentially a shortened version of the larger [[Chrysler/Simca Alpine|Alpine]], giving the vehicle an unusually wide track for its length. The Horizon, or ''Project C2'' as it was known inside Simca during development, was intended to be a "world car" (designed for consumers on both sides of the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]]), but, in execution, the European and [[North America]]n versions of the vehicle actually turned out to have very little in common. When Chrysler exited the European car market (and sold assets to [[Peugeot]], which subsequently sold the same car in Europe as the [[Talbot Horizon]]) in 1978, Chrysler retained the North American rights to the car, and began production at [[Belvidere, Illinois|Belvidere]]. [[File:Plymouth-Horizon-1.jpg|thumb|right|Plymouth Horizon]] Chrysler had previously avoided building a subcompact car, preferring to use [[captive import|branded imports]] like the [[Mitsubishi Motors|Mitsubishi]]-made [[Dodge Colt]] instead. Presented as a significant domestic development, the models were initially priced starting at US$2,500. The Dodge Omni was ''[[Motor Trend]]'' magazine's [[Car of the Year]] for 1978, and the related Talbot Horizon was voted [[European Car of the Year]] in 1979. The Omni and Horizon appeared at a critical time for Chrysler, when the company was on the brink of bankruptcy and sought government support to survive. In 1978, Chrysler had beaten out Ford and General Motors to the market with a domestically-produced front-wheel drive car to challenge the [[Volkswagen Golf Mk1|VW Rabbit]].{{cite web|url= http://www.autos.ca/motoring-memories/motoring-memories-dodge-omniplymouth-horizon-1978-1990/|first=Bill |last=Vance |title=Motoring Memories: Dodge Omni/Plymouth Horizon, 1978-1990 |publisher=autos canada |date=28 April 2006 |accessdate=12 January 2013 }} However, the L-bodies miscarried at first, since 1978 was a year of strong sales for larger cars and demand for compacts and subcompacts noticeably shrank. These initial poor sales of the cars contributed to Chrysler's financial woes at the time, but when the company requested federal assistance, the Omni was an important piece of evidence that they were attempting to compete with imports and build small, fuel-efficient cars and might be worth saving. For the three years leading up to the introduction of [[Chrysler K platform|Chrysler's K-cars]], the Omni/Horizon was Chrysler's best selling model line.{{cite journal | ref = 81bg | journal = Road & Track's Road Test Annual & Buyer's Guide 1981 | issue = January–February 1981 | title = 1981 Buyer's Guide | editor-first = Tony | editor-last = Hogg | page = 93 }} The Omni and Horizon had few interchangeable parts with their European siblings. Aside from the heavier-looking American body panels and bumpers, the [[Overhead valve|OHV]] Simca engines were replaced with unique 1.7 L SOHC engines sourced from [[Volkswagen]], while [[MacPherson strut]] front suspension took the place of the [[torsion bar]] arrangement found in the European Horizon. The Volkswagen engine used an enlarged Chrysler-designed [[cylinder head]] and [[intake manifold]] and produced {{convert|75|hp|kW|abbr=on}} and {{convert|90|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}}. Originally, only the [[California Air Resources Board|CARB]]-certified version with an air pump and {{convert|70|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} had been available.{{citation | ref = RT79 | title = An inside job on the imports | work = Road & Track's Road Test Annual & Buyer's Guide 1979 | date = January–February 1979 | publisher = CBS Publications | location = Greenwich, CT | page = 166 }} In 1979 power climbed to {{convert|77|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, while by 1980 it dropped to {{convert|68|hp|kW|abbr=on}} and {{convert|83|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} of torque in all fifty states.''[[#RT79|R&T Buyer's Guide 1979]]'', p. 93 The climate controls were mounted to the left of the steering wheel rather than in the center stack like in most vehicles, meaning only the driver could adjust the interior temperature. Other Chrysler Corporation products (including the [[Dodge Charger (B-body)|Dodge Charger]] and [[Chrysler Cordoba]]), as well as vehicles from other manufacturers came with instrument panels that placed the climate controls in this general location during the 1970s. Shortly after their introduction, ''[[Consumer Reports]]'' tested the Omni and reported that it lost control in hard maneuvering. As front-wheel-drive cars were still considered a new idea in Detroit, the allegation received extensive mainstream coverage, including a piece in ''[[Time Magazine]]''.{{cite journal|url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,916240,00.html |title=Storm over Omni-Horizon |date=26 June 1978 |journal=Time |accessdate=12 January 2013 }} Other auto magazines reported no problems and said the test did not approximate real-world driving conditions. Chrysler made modifications that included a steering damper and a lighter-weight steering wheel. A special, partially equipped, model with extra high gas mileage also appeared, called the "Miser". Chrysler's 2.2 L [[Chrysler K engine|K-car engine]] appeared for the 1981 model year as an upmarket option to the Volkswagen engine, mated to a new four-speed manual with an overdrive fourth. It produced {{convert|84|hp|kW|abbr=on}} at first, rising to {{convert|93|hp|kW|abbr=on}} and finally {{convert|96|hp|kW|abbr=on}} by the end of production. The Volkswagen 1.7 was replaced by a [[Simca 1100 engine|Simca]] 1.6 L [[Inline-four engine|inline-four]] unit in 1983. This engine produced {{convert|62|hp|kW|abbr=on}} and {{convert|86|lbft|N.m|abbr=on}}, and was only available with a [[manual transmission]]. The Omni/Horizon received a facelift for the 1984 model year. In 1985, Chrysler entered an agreement with [[American Motors|American Motors Corporation]] (AMC) to produce [[Chrysler M platform]] rear-wheel drive cars, as well as Omnis and Horizons, in AMC's [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]] plant, because AMC could produce the cars for less money. The 2.2 L Chrysler [[Inline-four engine|inline-four cylinder]] was the only available engine from 1987 onwards. By this point, the L-bodies were consolidated into a single-trim "America" line in the interest of improved quality control and reduced costs. Despite the P-body Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance effectively superseding the Omni/Horizon in 1987, the cars were kept in production for another three years since their tooling had been amortized and each one sold turned a profit. Chrysler invested in a number of significant changes that ended up being used for only one year; the cars gained larger exterior rear-view mirrors (borrowed from the departed [[Chrysler M platform|M-body]] sedans), a driver's side airbag and a mildly redesigned instrument panel, complete with HVAC controls moved to the center. The Omni and the Horizon ended production in 1990, and were replaced by the [[Dodge Shadow]]/[[Plymouth Sundance]], which were both introduced for 1987. It outlived the European version by three years; [[Peugeot]] had bought [[Chrysler Europe|Chrysler's European division]] in 1978 and rebadged the Horizon (along with the rest of the British Chrysler and French Simca range) as [[Talbot]]s, with production lasting until 1987.{{cite web|url=http://www.rootes-chrysler.co.uk/car-development/dev-horizon.html |title=Development of the Chrysler - Talbot - Simca Horizon |publisher=Rootes-chrysler.co.uk |date= |accessdate=12 January 2013 }} And, the Dodge Omni is a super lit car fam. ==Variants== Several variants of the platform appeared later, including a three-door hatchback known as the [[Dodge 024]]/[[Plymouth TC3]], and briefly a small car-like truck under the [[Dodge Rampage]]/[[Plymouth Scamp]] name. The 024 and TC3 were marketed as sporty cars, although the {{convert|77|-|94|hp|kW|abbr=on}} four-cylinder engines were not powerful and the coupés weighed more than the hatchbacks. The TC3 was renamed the [[Plymouth Turismo]], and the 024 the [[Dodge Charger (L-body)|Dodge Charger]] in 1983. The last 1,000 Dodge Chargers were modified by [[Carroll Shelby]] into [[Shelby GLHS]]s. ==Omni GLH== [[File:Dodge Omni GLH 91 race car.jpg|thumb|right|1984-1985 Dodge Omni GLH]] The ultimate Dodge Omni was the modified '''Omni GLH'''. The original name, "Coyote", was rejected, and Carroll Shelby's choice, the initials GLH, which stood for "Goes Like Hell", were taken instead.{{cite web|url=http://editorial.autos.msn.com/article.aspx?cp-documentid=434398&topart=sports|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071207210250/http://editorial.autos.msn.com/article.aspx?cp-documentid=434398&topart=sports|url-status=dead|archive-date=2007-12-07|title=Cool Cars We Miss|author=Griffey, Evan|publisher=MSN|year=2007|accessdate=2007-12-11}}{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=DZiRmOf3e5cC&pg=PA196&dq=Dodge+Omni+GLH+Goes+Like+Hell |page=196 |title=Dodge and Plymouth Muscle Car 1964-2000 |first=Peter C. |last=Sessler |publisher=Motorbooks |year=2001 |isbn=9780760308011 |accessdate=2015-11-03}} The 1984 model year was the first year of the GLH, which carried over most of the modifications that had been made the previous year to the [[Dodge Charger (L-body)|Shelby Charger]]. 1985 was the debut of the GLH-T model with the [[Chrysler K engine#2.2 Turbo I|Turbo I (K)]] engine option. This engine, rated at 146hp both years, at low boost (7.2 PSi) coupled with the car's very low weight (as low as {{convert|2200|lb|kg|abbr=on}}), earned this car its name. The car carried over into 1986 unchanged aside from the addition of a hatch-mounted third tail light, and production was then stopped. [[File:'86 Shelby GLHS (Orange Julep '09).jpg|thumb|right|1986 Shelby GLHS]] The final 500 GLH-T cars (all black) were sold to Shelby, who used them as the basis for the 1986 [[Shelby GLHS]] ("Goes Like Hell Some more").{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=AG_qCEWfMFsC&pg=PA209&dq=Dodge+Omni+GLH+Goes+Like+Hell |page=209 |title=The Complete Book of Shelby Automobiles |first=Colin |last=Comer T. |publisher=Motorbooks |year=2009 |isbn=9780760335789 |accessdate=2015-11-03}} These cars were modified by Carroll Shelby in California and sold as Shelbys. With {{convert|175|hp|kW|0}} and {{convert|175|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque, the Shelby GLHS featured a modified 2.2 L engine with a Turbo II setup, which included a two piece blow-through intake (the GLH-T was a draw-through turbo design), a Shelby ECU, turbo boost raised to a conservative 12 psi, a T2 turbocharger compressor cover, and a front-mounted intercooler. The short block stayed the same between the GLH-T and GLHS. Further modifications included 205/50R15 Eagle GT Gatorback tires mounted on Shelby Centurian wheels, Koni adjustable struts and shocks, and stiffer springs. Different decals were also part of the package; silver pinstripes down the ground effects along with "Shelby" decals replaced the standard red GLH-T decals. A "Shelby" decal was added to the windshield and a large "GLHS" decal was placed on the driver side rear sail panel. All GLHS cars came with a numbered dashboard plaque, Mobil 1 valve cover plaque, Momo shift knob and Shelby leather-wrapped steering wheel. A black-yellow overlay sticker was placed at the bottom of the speedometer to read to 135 mph. ==Production numbers== {| class=wikitable |- ! Year|| Sales |- |1978|| 81,611 |- |1979|| 141,477 |- |1980|| 138,155 |- |1981|| 77,039 |- |1982|| 71,864 |- |1983|| 42,554 |- |1984|| 71,355 |- |1985|| 74,127 |- |1986|| 73,580 |- |1987|| 66,907 |- |1988|| 59,867 |- |1989|| 46,239 |- |1990|| 16,733 |} Production stopped on February 2, 1990, with a total of 961,508 Omnis/Horizons assembled. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Plymouth Horizon}} {{Commons category|Dodge Omni}} *[http://www.allpar.com/omni/omni.html Allpar's Omni/Horizon page] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091027053606/http://geocities.com/MotorCity/2086/ Plymouth Horizon-o-Rama] *[http://www.canadiandriver.com/articles/bv/omni-horizon.htm Canadian Driver] *[http://www.front-runners.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17&Itemid=29 Front-Runners.net Road Test] ([[PDF]]) {{Dodge}} {{Dodge timeline 1950–1979}} {{Dodge timeline 1980 to date}} {{Dodge Timeline}} {{Dodge Canada Timeline}} {{Plymouth Timeline}} {{Plymouth}} [[Category:Dodge vehicles|Omni]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Subcompact cars]] [[Category:Hatchbacks]] [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:1990s cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1977]]

From the 1965 to 1975 [[model year]]s the name was on [[Mid-size car|intermediate-sized]] models. A ''[[coronet]]'' is a small [[Crown (headgear)|crown]] consisting of ornaments fixed on a metal ring. ==First generation (1949–1952)== [[File:Chrysler Corporation automobiles and vans. 1946-1951models - NARA - 283792.jpg|thumb|left|1949 Dodge Coronet station wagon]] {{Infobox automobile | name = First generation | image = Dodge15.jpg | caption = 1949 Dodge Coronet 4-Door Sedan | production = 1949–1952 | assembly = [[Dodge Main|Dodge Main Factory]], [[Hamtramck, MI]] | body_style = 2-door [[coupe]]

{{convert|202.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (1950) | width = 74" }} ===1949=== The Dodge Coronet was introduced with the division's first postwar body styles. Lower trim lines were the [[Dodge Wayfarer|Wayfarer]] and Meadowbrook, with the Wayfarer being built on a shorter 115 inch wheelbase.{{cite journal |ref=AQ181 |journal=Automobile Quarterly |volume=XVIII |issue=1 |year=1980 |title=Wayward Wayfarer: The story of a Dodge |first=Jeffrey I. |last=Godshall |issn=0005-1438 |page=77}} The only engine for Dodge was a {{convert|230|cuin|cc|adj=on}} flat-head [[Straight-six engine|straight six cylinder]] engine with a single barrel [[Zenith Carburettor Company (British)|Stromberg carburetor]], producing {{convert|103|hp|0|abbr=on}} (gross). The stock Dodge Coronet was a smooth running car, and the six-cylinder engine could power the car to {{convert|90|mi/h|0|abbr=on}}+ . A limited production model was a four-door, eight-passenger limousine, an extended version of the stock Dodge Coronet. One of the most notable features of the first-generation Coronet was a three-speed, fluid-driven transmission that was operated by a foot pedal on the floor. It required no shifter. It had full instrumentation and 37 inches of head room both front and rear.{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1949_Dodge/1949_Dodge_D29-D30_Manual/1949%20Dodge%20D29%20%20amp%20%20D30%20Manual-07.html |title=1949 Dodge D29 D30 manual |page=4 |website=Old Car Brochures.com |date= |accessdate=January 3, 2016}}http://oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1949_Dodge/1949%20Dodge-2/image2.html ===1950=== [[File:1950 Dodge Coronet.jpg|thumb|left|1950 Dodge Coronet]] Dodge received a facelift for 1950 but like the 1949 models were still divided into Wayfarer, Meadowbrook and Coronet lines. The 1950 models can be identified easily by the new grille design which featured 3 heavy horizontal bars. The upper and lower bars formed a stylish oblong shape. Within this oblong grille was a thick center bar with parking lights on each end and a large chrome plaque in the center bearing the Dodge crest. The 8-passenger sedan's length was 216.8 inches. ===1951–1952=== [[File:1951 Dodge Coronet Club Coupe (5883506774).jpg|thumb|left|1951 Dodge Coronet Club Coupe]] [[File:1952 Dodge (35539748906).jpg|thumb|left|1952 Dodge Coronet Club Coupe]] Dodge received yet another facelift in 1951 but this time the cars remained virtually unchanged for two model years. Busy manufacturing military vehicles for use in Korea, they chose not to dedicate valuable resources to completely redesign civilian vehicles. Still divided into Wayfarer, Meadowbrook and Coronet lines through 1952, by 1953 the Wayfarer line had been discontinued. The grille of the 1951 model was similar in shape to the 1950 grille, but with the elimination of the thick vertical center bar and the addition of six vents running horizontally between the top and center bars, a whole new look was achieved. The Coronet Diplomat was Dodge's first hardtop-convertible, featuring a pillarless steel roof styled after the contemporary Chrysler Newport. The speedometer was now circular, and the other four gauges were rectangles. For 1952 the Coronet had a painted lower grille louver. {{clear}} ==Second generation (1953–1954)== {{Infobox automobile | name = Second generation | image = Low9OldDodgePrivateProperty.jpg | model_years = 1953–1954 | assembly = [[Dodge Main|Dodge Main Factory]], [[Hamtramck, MI]] | body_style = 4-door [[Sedan (automobile)|sedan]]
2-door [[coupe]] | related = [[DeSoto Fireflite]] | engine = {{convert|241|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|230|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Straight-six engine|I6]] | transmission = 2-speed automatic
3-speed manual
Gyrol fluid Drive
Gyro-Torque Drive | wheelbase = {{convert|119|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|201.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1953_Dodge/1953_Dodge_Brochure/1953%20Dodge-06.html |title=1953 Dodge Brochure |website=Old Car Brochures.com |date= |accessdate=November 20, 2011}} }} ===1953=== For 1953, the Coronet was totally redesigned. It gained an optional {{convert|241|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} "Red Ram"{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1954_Dodge/1954_Dodge_Brochure/1954%20Dodge-12.html |title=1954 Dodge brochure |page=12 |website=Old Car Brochures.com |date= |accessdate=January 3, 2016}} [[Chrysler Hemi engine|Hemi]] Engine and set over 100 land speed records at the [[Bonneville Salt Flats]].https://www.allpar.com/cars/dodge/coronet.html The windshield finally became one-piece. Electric windshield wipers were standard, while the radio cost $83. ===1954=== The [[Dodge Royal]] line was added above the Coronet in 1954. Dodge was putting more luxury into all of its models which included the [[Dodge Meadowbrook|Meadowbrook]], Coronet and new Royal lines. Still, styling changes for 1954 were modest. The chrome molding on the hood lip was wider than on the 1953 models and a large chrome upright in the center of the grille replaced the five vertical dividers used previously. It still came with full instrumentation.{{cite web |url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1954_Dodge/1954_Dodge_Owners_Manual/1954%20Dodge%20Owners%20Manual-06-07.html |title=1954 Dodge Owners Manual |website=Old Car Brochures.com |date= |accessdate=November 20, 2011}} 1954 saw Chrysler's first fully automatic transmission, two-speed [[PowerFlite]], offered as an extra-cost option on all Dodges. {{clear}} ==Third generation (1955–1956)== :''See also [[1955 Dodge]]'' [[File:1956 Dodge Coronet D63 V8 four-door sedan, front left (Hershey 2019).jpg|thumb|1956 Dodge Coronet 4-door sedan]] [[File:Dodge Coronet 1955.jpg|thumb|1956 Dodge Coronet coupe]] The 1955 Coronet dropped to the lower end of the Dodge vehicle lineup, with the Wayfarer and Meadowbrook names no longer used and the [[Dodge Custom Royal|Custom Royal]] added above the [[Dodge Royal|Royal]], [[Dodge Lancer|Lancer]], and [[Dodge La Femme|La Femme]]. Bodies were restyled with help from newly hired [[Virgil Exner]] to be lower, wider, and longer than the lumpy prewar style, which in turn generated a healthy boost in sales over 1954. Power came from either a {{convert|230|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler Flathead engine]] [[straight-6]], now producing {{convert|123|hp|abbr=on}} Two V8 engines were offered: {{convert|270|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Polyspheric]] (poly or semi-hemi) heads producing {{convert|175|hp|abbr=on}} and a {{convert|315|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} (the "[[Chrysler Hemi Engine|Hemi]]") Power windows were new.{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1955_Dodge/1955_Dodge_Brochure/1955%20Dodge-06.html |title=1955 Dodge brochure |website=Old Car Brochures.com |date= |accessdate=November 20, 2011}} Wheelbase was 120 inches. They were 212.1 inches long.{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1955_Dodge/1955_Dodge_Brochure/1955%20Dodge-07.html |title=1955 Dodge brochure |page=7 |website=Old Car Brochures.com |date= |accessdate=January 3, 2016}} A number of trim lines were available: *2- or 4-door [[station wagon]] — The Coronet wagon used the '''Suburban''' name and had the V8 or six *[[hardtop]] [[coupé]] — The V8 [[Dodge Lancer|Coronet Lancer]] *2- or 4-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]] — V8 or Six *2-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]] — V8 or Six *4-door, eight-passenger limousine 1956 (:''See also [[Plymouth Fury]]'') was the last year of this body style before the change in 1957, the only differences offered in 1956 from the previous year were trim packages and the new [[1955 Dodge#D-500|Dodge D-500]]. The D-500 was the first Dodge factory high performance made in honor of the (D-500-1) "Super Stock" model with the only external clues being discreet crossed checkered flags and "500" lettering on its hood and lower rear deck it was also available for order from the dealer on Coronet models, including station wagons and two-door sedans. The standard D-500 trim included a {{convert|315|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 with hemispherical heads (unlike other Dodge V8s ( [[List of Chrysler engines]]) which used [[Polyspheric]] heads), a unique [[camshaft]], valve lifters, pushrods, [[carburetor]], ignition, and pistons. With a compression ratio of 9.25:1, four-barrel Carter WCFB carburetor, and dual-point distribution, peak horsepower was {{convert|260|bhp|abbr=on}} while torque was a solid {{convert|330|lb·ft|N.m|abbr=on}}. The D-500 also received an upgraded suspension with stiff front coil springs; heavy duty Oriflow shock absorbers, with the same valving specified for Dodge police cars, were mounted in the springs. Similar units were used in the rear. Overall height of the D-500 was {{convert|1.5|in|mm}} lower than its standard Dodge counterpart. The D-500 came standard with 15x5.5 inch wheels with 7.60x15 inch tubeless tires. New for safety were safety door locks.{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1956_Dodge/1956_Dodge_Full_Line_Folder/1956%20Dodge%20Full%20Line%20Folder-07.html |title=1956 Dodge full line folder |website=Old Car Brochures.com |date= |accessdate=January 3, 2016}} The D-500-1 (the first 500 made required by NASCAR, was intended for NASCAR competition. The D-500-1 had an even stiffer suspension than the D-500. Under the hood, the engine received larger valves (about 18% larger), a full-race camshaft, and a double log intake [[manifold]] that used two four-barrel Carter WCFB carburetors and a shaved deck for 8.25:1 compression. This all added up to {{convert|285|bhp|abbr=on}}. It was the fastest car that year from the factory. ==Fourth generation (1957–1959)== [[File:1958 Dodge Coronet (14364512010).jpg|thumb|1958 Dodge Coronet sedan]] [[File:Dodge Coronet.jpg|thumb|1959 Dodge Coronet coupe]] The 1957 model year debuted a new D-501, which replaced the D-500 from the year before as the top Coronet. The D-501 received Chrysler's proven {{convert|354|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Hemi V8, which were actually left over engines from the 1956 Chrysler 300B production. Camshafts from the 1957 Chrysler 392 cid engines were installed in the 354 V8s. A pair of Carter four barrel carburetors fed the 10.0:1 compression ratio to produce {{convert|340|bhp|abbr=on}}. Other changes included the addition of the Torsion-Aire Ride (torsion bar) front suspension and a heavy duty suspension with heavy duty shock absorbers and a heavy duty leaf sprung rear. A 3.73:1 rear axle was standard with the three-speed manual transmission, but [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] cars received a 3.18:1 rear axle. There were 13 optional rear axles available, ranging from 2.92:1 through 6.17:1. The D-501 received 7.60x15 tires on 15x8 inch wheels. Brakes were {{convert|12|in|mm|adj=on}} diameter drums. Only 101 D-501s were produced. A padded dash was optional.{{cite web |url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Dodge/1957_Dodge/1957_Dodge_Brochure/1957%20Dodge-08-09.html |title=1957 Dodge brochure |website=Old Car Brochures.com |date= |accessdate=November 20, 2011}} In the September 1957 issue of [[Popular Mechanics]], owners of both the Coronet six-cylinder and eight-cylinder were surveyed.{{cite book |title=Popular Mechanics |date=September 1957 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DeEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA134&dq=Dodge+coronet&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwici9vW-8LgAhVs3IMKHTeZDLcQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&q=Dodge%20coronet&f=false |accessdate=17 February 2019}} Many people (37.6% of I6 owners and 34.8% of V8 owners) complained that there were too many water leaks. When PM tested a V8 Coronet for water resistance, water got into the engine and pooled in "two spark plug wells" which had to be siphoned out before the engine could run with all cylinders again.{{cite book |title=Popular Mechanics |date=September 1957 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DeEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA134&dq=Dodge+coronet&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwici9vW-8LgAhVs3IMKHTeZDLcQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&q=Dodge%20coronet&f=false |accessdate=17 February 2019}} However, many did like the exterior styling and the ride comfort. 0-60mph on 90 octane gasoline was 12.3 seconds. The 1958 and 1959 Coronet, Royal, and Custom Royal used a [[DeSoto Fireflite]] chassis but had less ornate trim. Power came from the {{convert|230|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler Flathead engine|"Getaway" L-head]] [[straight-6]] or the {{convert|325|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler FirePower engine#326|"Red Ram"]] V8. In 1959 a Silver Challenger model was also offered on the Coronet line. This was a six-cylinder or V-8 model available only in silver paint and only on a two-door body. It came with many extra features at no cost, such as wall-to-wall deep pile carpeting, premium white wall tires and wheel covers, luxury fabrics and upgraded interior and electric windshield wipers.{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/files/1959_0603_dodge.jpg |title=1959 Dodge |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=March 23, 2011}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The overall length was inctreased to 217.4 inches. The Dodge Custom Royal was also assembled by [[Chrysler Australia]] from early 1958 to 1960.{{cite book |title=Great ideas in motion: Chrysler's Australian history 1946–1981 |first=Gavin |last=Farmer |location=Bridgewater, South Australia |publisher=Ilinga Books |year=2010 |isbn=978-0-98052-291-4 |page=74 & 412}} A Dodge Coronet was the only known example of the [[JATO Rocket Car]] legend. To publicize Dodge's 'total contact' front dual-leading shoe drum brakes a [[JATO]] unit was fitted to a 1958 Coronet and driven at speed across the [[El Mirage Lake|El Mirage dry lake]]. This TV advertisement was broadcast during Dodge-sponsored [[Lawrence Welk Show]].{{YouTube|ZGEjFh-GCUo|title=Dodge presents The Lawrence Welk Show}}, segment begins at 30:00 {{-}} ==={{anchor|Silver Challenger (1959)}}1959 Dodge Silver Challenger=== {{Infobox automobile | image = 1959 Dodge Silver Challenger a "Barn Find".jpg | name = Dodge Silver Challenger | body_style = 2-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]] | class = [[Full-size car]] | related = [[Dodge Coronet#Fourth generation (1957–1959)|Dodge Coronet (fourth generation)]] }} The first car that carried the [[Dodge Challenger|Challenger]] name was introduced as the limited edition ''Dodge Silver Challenger'' Club Sedan, an addition to the 1959 full-sized [[Dodge Coronet#Fourth generation (1957–1959)|Dodge Coronet (fourth generation)]] model line produced in Detroit, Michigan.{{Cite web|url=http://hooniverse.com/2014/04/25/hooniverse-obscure-muscle-car-garage-the-1959-dodge-silver-challenger/|title=Hooniverse Obscure Muscle Car Garage – The 1959 Dodge Silver Challenger|last=Erickson|first=Keith|date=April 25, 2014|website=Hooniverse|access-date=August 27, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170828062551/http://hooniverse.com/2014/04/25/hooniverse-obscure-muscle-car-garage-the-1959-dodge-silver-challenger/|archive-date=August 28, 2017|url-status=dead}} The Silver Challenger came only in silver paint and exclusively on Chrysler's {{convert|217.4|in|mm|abbr=on}} long two-door, on a {{convert|122|in|mm|abbr=on}} wheelbase. It was available with either the {{convert|230|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler Flathead engine|"Getaway" L-head]] [[straight-six engine]] for $2,297, or the {{convert|326|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler FirePower engine#326|"Red Ram"]] [[V8 engine|V8]] for $2,408.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l096ebZSm9EC&pg=PA96&lpg=PA96&dq=A+special+Silver+Challenger+Club+Sedan+was+released+on+June+1,+1959|title=Standard guide to 1950s American cars|last=Gunnell|first=John|publisher=KP Books|year=2004|isbn=978-0-87349-868-5|page=96|accessdate=July 13, 2014}} This car was marketed for the spring selling season to "new-car buyers who've been waiting to get the most for the least."{{cite web|url= http://www.forwardlook.net/forums/forums/thread-view.asp?tid=29389|title=1959 Dodge mid-year Silver Challenger edition |author=soiouz |date=14 February 2010 |publisher=forwardlook.net |accessdate=July 13, 2014}} A column-shifted three-speed [[manual transmission]] was standard and an [[automatic transmission|automatic]] was optional. The 1959 Silver Challenger was marketed with extra features at no extra cost. These included premium [[white wall tire]]s, full [[Hubcap|wheel covers]], electric windshield wipers, as well as an upgraded interior with silver metallic vinyl and black "Manchu" fabric upholstery, dual arm rests and [[sun visor]]s, as well as deep pile wall-to-wall carpeting.{{cite press release |url=http://www.challengertalk.com/forums/attachments/f5/41720d1325917185-1959-dodge-challenger-59-dodge-silver-challenger-side.jpg |title=1959 Dodge Silver Challenger (Dodge Public Relations) |publisher=challengertalk.com |accessdate=July 13, 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008171458/http://www.challengertalk.com/forums/attachments/f5/41720d1325917185-1959-dodge-challenger-59-dodge-silver-challenger-side.jpg |archivedate=October 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} {{-}} ==Fifth generation (1965–1970)== ===1965–1967=== {{Infobox automobile |name = Fifth generation |assembly = [[Hamtramck, Michigan]], [[United States]]
