In late 2005, Dodge teased spy photos of the Dodge Challenger prototype on the internet and it was announced on November 21, 2005 showing an official drawing sketch of the vehicle.<ref>{{cite web |title=2006 Dodge Challenger concept car |url=https://www.allpar.com/cars/concepts/dodge/challenger-concept.html |website=allpar.com}}</ref> The Dodge Challenger Concept was unveiled at the [[North American International Auto Show#2006|2006 North American International Auto Show]] and was a preview for the 3rd generation Dodge Challenger that started its production in 2008. Many design cues of the Dodge Challenger Concept were adapted from the 1970 Dodge Challenger R/T. It was the second pony car to reuse a previous design in the 2000s, after the 2005 [[Ford Mustang]] but before the 2010 [[Chevrolet Camaro]] (which was revived after seven years of being out of production).
===Initial release=== On December 3, 2007, Chrysler started taking deposits for the 3rd-generation Dodge Challenger which debuted on February 6, 2008, simultaneously at the [[Chicago Auto Show]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edmunds.com/insideline/do/News/articleId=123858 |title=Dodge Swamped With Challenger Orders |publisher=Inside Line |date=December 6, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080131221116/http://www.edmunds.com/insideline/do/News/articleId%3D123858 |archivedate=January 31, 2008 |accessdate=July 13, 2014 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and Philadelphia International Auto Show. Listing at US$40,095, the new version was a 2-door [[notchback]] [[coupe]] (seating 5 passengers with over 33 cubic feet of rear passenger volume) which shared common design elements with the first generation Challenger, despite being significantly longer and taller. As with Chevrolet's new Camaro, the Challenger [[concept car]]'s [[pillar (car)|pillarless]] [[hardtop]] body was replaced with a fixed "B" pillar, hidden behind the side glass to give an illusion of the hardtop. The LC chassis is a modified (shortened wheelbase) version of the LX platform that underpins the [[Dodge Charger (LX)]], [[Dodge Magnum]], and the [[Chrysler 300]]. The LX was developed in America from the previous Chrysler LH platform, which had been designed to allow it to be easily upgraded to rear and all-wheel drive. Many Mercedes components were incorporated, or used for inspiration, including the Mercedes-Benz W220 S-class control arm front suspension, the Mercedes-Benz W211 E-Class 5-link rear suspension, the W5A580 5-speed automatic, the rear differential, and the ESP system. All (7119) 2008 models were SRT8s and equipped with the {{convert|370|cuin|L|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} Hemi V8 engine and a 5-speed AutoStick [[automatic transmission]]. The entire 2008 Canadian produced run of 6,400 US market cars were pre-sold and production commenced on May 8, 2008.
Chrysler of Mexico offered only 100 SRT8s, with a 6.1 liter V8 engine rated at {{convert|425|hp}} (SAE). Chrysler auctioned off two 2008 SRT8s for charity with the first car going for US$400,000 and a "B5" Blue No.43 car with a winning bid of US$228,143.43.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.redletterdodge.com/2008/02/23/sold-43-dodge-challenger-srt8-raises-22814343-for-charity/ |title=SOLD! No.43 Dodge Challenger SRT/8 Raises $228,143.43 for Charity|publisher=Dodge.com |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081205140407/http://www.redletterdodge.com/2008/02/23/sold-43-dodge-challenger-srt8-raises-22814343-for-charity/ |archivedate=December 5, 2008 |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref>
The base model Challenger SE was initially powered by a {{convert|214|cuin|L|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} [[Chrysler SOHC V6 engine#3.5|SOHC V6 engine]] rated at {{convert|250|hp|0|abbr=on}} (SAE) and {{convert|250|lbfft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque which was coupled to a 4-speed automatic transmission for the first half of 2009, and was then changed to have a standard 5-speed automatic transmission.<ref name="2009jbspecs">{{cite web|url= http://www.jbcarpages.com/dodge/challenger/2009/specs/ |title=2009 Dodge Challenger Specs |publisher=JB car pages |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> Several different exterior colors, with either cloth or leather interiors became available. Standard features included air conditioning, power windows, locks, and mirrors; cruise control, and {{convert|17|in|mm|adj=on}} aluminum wheels. Leather upholstery, heated front seats, sunroof, 18-inch aluminum wheels, and a premium audio system are available as options, as are ABS, and stability and traction control.<ref name="2009jbreview">{{cite web|url= http://www.jbcarpages.com/dodge/challenger/2009/ |title=2009 Dodge Challenger Review |publisher=JB car pages |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> The Canadian market also sports the SXT trim, similar to the SE, but more generous in terms of standard features. Some of these features being ESP, an alarm system, and {{convert|18|in|mm|adj=on}} wheels. Starting with the 2012 model year, the SE was replaced in the U.S. with the SXT model.
Previous to the 2012 model year, the SXT version of the Challenger was only sold in Canada and is a more well-equipped variation of the SE. It adds fog lamps, a rear spoiler, larger wheels, illuminated vanity mirrors, security alarm and a leather-wrapped shifter. In addition, the SXT has increased option packages available to it that aren't available on the SE, and are also available to the R/T. (Such as the high-end navigation-enabled entertainment system.)
====Challenger 500==== Chrysler Canada offered a further 670 SRTs uniquely badged as the Challenger 500 (paying homage to Charger and Coronet 500s) all of which were shipped to Canadian Dodge dealers.
===2009 model year=== {{Multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = 200 | image1= 2010 Dodge Challenger RT Classic.JPG | caption1= 2010 Dodge Challenger R/T | image2= 2010 Detonator Challenger RT Classic.jpg | caption2= 2010 Dodge Challenger R/T Classic in Detonator Yellow | image3= Dodge Challenger SRT8.JPG | caption3= 2010 Dodge Challenger SRT-8 }}
Production of the limited edition 2008 SRT8s ended in July 2008, and production of the expanded 2009 line-up started in early August of the same year. The expanded offering was the same as had been unveiled earlier that spring at the 2008 [[New York Auto Show]]. Chrysler debuted the full Dodge Challenger line-up for 2009, with four different trims – SE, R/T, SRT8, and the SXT in Canada only. In addition to the SRT8, which remained unchanged except for the optional 6 speed manual and standard limited slip differential, the line-up included the previously mentioned SE and SXT which offered the {{convert|250|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 3.5-Liter V6. The R/T hosted a 5.7 Hemi sporting {{convert|372|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|398|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} of torque when coupled with the 5 speed automatic, and {{convert|375|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} with {{convert|404|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} when matched with the same Tremec 6-speed manual transmission as the SRT8.
New for 2009 was the Rallye Package for the SE model. The package featured design cues including dual body stripes on the hood and the trunk, chromed fuel cap, deck lid spoiler, 18-inch aluminum wheels, and Micro Carbon interior accents.
The mid-level Challenger R/T is powered by a {{convert|345|cuin|L|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} [[Chrysler Hemi Engine|Hemi]] V8 coupled to a 5-speed automatic transmission or a Tremec TR-6060 6-speed manual transmission. On cars equipped with the automatic transmission, the engine features the [[Multi-Displacement System]] and is rated at {{convert|372|hp||abbr=on}} (SAE) and {{convert|398|lbfft|Nm|abbr=on}} torque.<ref name="2009jbspecs"/> With the 6-speed manual transmission, the [[Multi-Displacement System]] option was deleted and the engine is rated at {{convert|375|hp|0|abbr=on}} (SAE) and {{convert|404|lbfft|Nm|abbr=on}} torque.<ref name="2009jbspecs"/> Another feature was the Intelligent Deceleration Fuel Shut-Off (iDFSO) available for the automatic models only. The first to combine both a Multi-Displacement system and fuel shut-off.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.allpar.com/news/index.php/2009/07/chrysler-adds-fuel-shutoff-to-increase-mileage |title=Chrysler adds fuel shutoff to increase mileage | Allpar Chrysler, Dodge, and Jeep News |publisher=Allpar.com |date=July 7, 2009 |first=David |last=Zatz |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> The [[final drive ratio]] was 3.06:1 on cars with the automatic transmission, 3.73:1 on cars with the 6-speed manual and {{convert|18|in|mm|adj=on}} wheels or 3.92:1 with the 6-speed manual and optional {{convert|20|in|mm|adj=on}} wheels. Also available on R/T was the "Track Pak" option group, which includes the Tremec manual transmission, a limited slip differential and self-leveling rear shock absorbers.
The Challenger R/T Classic has retro aspects such as script "Challenger" badges on the front panels and black or white "R/T" stripes. It comes with a five-speed automatic standard, with an optional six-speed manual transmission including a pistol-grip-shifter. The wheels are Heritage 20" Torq-Thrust style specials. It became available in Brilliant Black Crystal Pearl, Bright Silver Metallic, Stone White and in multiple "heritage" colors: Toxic Orange, HEMI-Orange, TorRed, B5 Blue, Plum Crazy Purple, Detonator Yellow and Furious Fuchsia. Production started in February 2009.
The 2009 SRT8, while still equipped with the 6.1 L (370 cu in) Hemi V8, is virtually identical to its 2008 counterpart, with the main difference being the choice of either a 5-speed automatic or a 6-speed manual transmission. Standard features include Brembo brakes, a sport suspension, bi-xenon headlamps, heated leather sport seats, keyless go, Sirius satellite radio, and {{convert|20|in|mm|adj=on}} forged aluminum wheels in addition to most amenities offered on the R/T and SE models such as air conditioning and cruise control.<ref name="2009jbreview"/> In addition, the 2009 had a "limited slip" differential that was not offered on the 2008 model.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.challengertalk.com/forums/f30/summary-srt-chat-session-2017/ |title=SRT Engineers Chat Session |publisher=Challenger Forum |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> A "Spring Special" SRT8 Challenger was also offered in B5 Blue, but due to rolling plant shutdowns, just over 250 Spring Special Challengers were built before the end of the 2009 model year.
The '''Mopar '10 Challenger R/T''' is a limited version of the 2010 Challenger R/T with metallic pearl black body color, three accent colors (blue, red, silver) of stripes to choose from. In addition, these cars were available with black R/T Classic-style wheels along with a Hurst aftermarket pistol grip shifter, custom badging, Mopar cold air intake for a ten-horsepower increase, and a Katzkin-sourced aftermarket interior. The cars were built in [[Brampton Assembly]] and completed at the Mopar Upfit Center in Windsor, Ontario. There were 500 U.S. Units and 100 Canadian units built. Of the 500 Mopar special edition U.S. versions, 320 had automatic transmissions, 180 had manuals, while 255 had blue stripes, 115 had red stripes, and 130 had silver stripes. A limited numbered run of 400 SRTs in 2010 were produced with "Furious Fuchsia" paint and white leather seats with horizontal fuchsia colored slash bars on the back rests. Special badging on the passenger side dash script denotes the production number of each individual car ranging from the numbers 1 to 400. Dodge marketed this package as homage to the original Panther Pink cars 40 years previous. These cars came with both automatic and Tremec six speed transmissions.
The Drag Race Package is a race model designed for [[NHRA]] competition, based on the Dodge Challenger SRT-8. The car is {{convert|1000|lb|0|abbr=on}} lighter than the street vehicle by eliminating major production components and systems. To accentuate the weight savings, they also feature added composite, polycarbonate and lightweight components designed for drag racing that is part of the new Package Car program. The engine was repositioned to improve driveline angle and weight distribution. The {{convert|116|in|mm|adj=on}} wheelbase was shortened by ½ inch. The car also features a front cradle with bolt-in crossmember and solid engine mounts.
At least 50 Challenger Drag Race Package Cars are being built to meet NHRA requirements. Engine options include a 6.1liter HEMI, 5.7-liter HEMI, and a 5.9-liter Magnum Wedge. Manual or automatic transmissions are available, and the rear axle is solid (not IRS). An initial run of the required 50 cars was completed and over 100 of the "2009 Challenger Drag Pak" vehicles were produced. "Big Daddy" [[Don Garlits]] bought the first drag race package car and has raced it in NHRA competition.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://jalopnik.com/398484/mopar-dodge-challenger-drag-pack-finally-revealed |title=Mopar Dodge Challenger Drag Pack Finally Revealed |publisher=Jalopnik.com |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> The prototype cars shown at SEMA were built by MPR Racing of Michigan, who continue to modify the production cars as delivered from Chrysler.
===2010 model year=== In its second year of production, the Challenger received only a few minor feature and option changes. Electronic stability control is newly standard across the entire Challenger model line. R/T models gained the following standard features: automatic headlamps, an LED-lit cupholder and door-handle lights. UConnect Multimedia and UConnect Navigation options now include steering-wheel audio controls while UConnect Multimedia features have been combined with the optional Sound Group.
The most significant new option for 2010 is the Super Track Pack, which brings a host of track-ready hardware and upgrades that includes: * 20x9 wheels with Goodyear F1 Super Car tires * Front and rear Sachs Nivomat self-leveling shock-absorbers * Larger rear stabilizer bar (20mm > 16mm stock) * Variable displacement performance steering pump (standard on 6 speed) * 3.06 rear-axle ratio (n/a on 6-speed R/Ts which maintain 3.92 ratio) * Anti-lock 4-Wheel disc heavy duty brakes with performance brake linings * "ESP-off" stability calibration. A limited slip differential remained standard only on R/Ts equipped with the 6 speed manual transmission.<ref>https://www.nadaguides.com/Cars/2010/Dodge/Challenger</ref>
===2011 model year=== {{Multiple image | align = right| direction = vertical | width = 200 |image1= 2011 DODGE CHALLENGER SRT8.jpg |caption1= 2011 Dodge Challenger SRT8 |image2= Dodge Challenger SRT-8 (5483331098).jpg |caption2= 2011 Dodge Challenger SRT8 badge on [[Spoiler (car)|rear spoiler]] | image3= Dodge Challenger SRT-8 (2011) - 6.4L 392 Hemi V8 Engine - 2.jpg | caption3= The 6.4-liter HEMI V8 engine used in the SRT8 }}
The Ram emblem disappeared with the 2011 model year (as the namesake truck was being spun off as [[Ram Trucks|its own brand]]), and Challengers received two new engines, the Pentastar, and a 392 Hemi. * The SE and SE Rallye received the new 3.6-liter [[Chrysler Pentastar engine|Pentastar]] V6 engine rated at {{convert|305|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|268|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}}, dual rear exhaust with bright tips, a five-speed automatic transmission with AutoStick, 18-inch aluminum wheels, advanced brake systems including: four-wheel disc antilock brakes, brake assist, ready alert braking and rain brake support, electronic stability control (ESC), with hill start assist and all-speed traction control, a chrome fuel filler door, Uconnect 130 System with AM/FM radio, CD player, six speakers and auxiliary input jack, steering wheel-mounted audio and speed control, twin hood scoops, touring suspension, remote keyless entry, six airbags, active front head restraints, premium cloth seating, six-way power driver seat with four-way power lumbar adjust, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, air conditioning with automatic temperature control, keyless enter and go with proximity sensor and push button start, power windows, locks and mirrors along with a tilt/telescoping steering column and 60/40 folding rear seats that include a rear armrest with cup holders. * In 2011, the Challenger Rallye Package added dual red out-lined center stripes, premium leather interior with heated front seats, body-color rear spoiler, performance-tuned steering with sport suspension and handling package, further upgraded brakes, and unique Foose designed 18-inch Rallye wheels.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.automoblog.net/2010/10/22/dodge-challenger-gets-pentastar-v-6-for-2011/ |title=Dodge Challenger Gets Pentastar V-6 for 2011|publisher=Automoblog.net|date=October 22, 2010 |first=Tony |last=Pimpo |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> * The R/T received revisions including a new bottom grille cutout and an updated suspension. * The new SRT8's chin spoiler was enlarged to create more downforce. It resembles the 1970 Challenger R/T. The SRT8 received a new 6.4-liter Hemi V8.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.media.chrysler.com/dcxms/assets/specs/2011_Challenger392_Specifications.pdf |title=2011 Dodge Challenger SRT8 392 Specs |publisher=Media.Chrysler.com |accessdate=July 13, 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916011533/http://www.media.chrysler.com/dcxms/assets/specs/2011_Challenger392_Specifications.pdf |archivedate=September 16, 2012 |df=mdy }}</ref> The so-called 392 (although its actual size is 391 cu-in.) was officially rated at {{convert|470|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|470|lbft|0|abbr=on}} of torque. Dodge engineers stated they sacrificed peak horsepower ratings for low-end torque, stating a {{Convert|90|lbft|0|abbr=on}} increase over the outgoing 6.1-L (370 c.i.d.) Hemi V8 at 2,900 rpm.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.caranddriver.com/news/car/10q4/2011_dodge_challenger_srt8_392-official_photos_and_info |title=2011 Dodge Challenger SRT8 392 – Official Photos and Info |publisher=caranddriver.com |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=July 13, 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005174704/http://www.caranddriver.com/news/car/10q4/2011_dodge_challenger_srt8_392-official_photos_and_info |archivedate=October 5, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Two transmissions were offered: a 5-Speed Shiftable Automatic and a 6-speed manual. With the revised 6.4-liter engine, Chrysler engineers cited a quarter mile (~400 m) time of 12.4 seconds at {{convert|110|mph|0|abbr=on}} – bettering the outgoing 6.1-Liter Hemi by 0.8 seconds, although that figure has varied wildly between automotive magazines. ''Car and Driver'' tested the 392 at 12.9 seconds at {{convert|114|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/car/10q4/2011_dodge_challenger_srt8_392-short_take_road_test |title=2011 Dodge Challenger SRT8 392 – First Drive: Dodge Challenger Review |publisher=caranddriver.com |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=July 13, 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928000824/http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/car/10q4/2011_dodge_challenger_srt8_392-short_take_road_test |archivedate=September 28, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> while ''Motor Trend'' tested it at 13.0 seconds at {{convert|111.3|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/coupes/1011_2011_dodge_challenger_srt8_392_test/specs.html |title=2011 Dodge Challenger SRT8 392 – Official Photos and Info|publisher=motortrend.com|date=December 3, 2010 |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> and Edmunds' number was far closer to Chrysler's claimed numbers at 12.6 seconds at {{convert|112.1|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.insideline.com/dodge/challenger/2011/2011-dodge-challenger-srt8-392-full-test.html |title=2011 Dodge Challenger SRT8 392 Full Test |publisher=insideline.com |date=December 10, 2010 |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> * Top speeds of the 2011 Dodge Challenger R/T and 2011 Dodge Challenger SRT8 were both rated at {{Convert|170|mph|0|abbr=on}}. The R/T has a 0 to 60 mph (0 to 97 km/h) acceleration time of 5.00 seconds, while the SRT8 accelerates to 60 mph (97 km/h) in 4.50 seconds.
===2012 model year=== The base SE trim was renamed to SXT for consistency with the naming scheme of the remaining Dodge lineup. The SRT8 392 model gains a two-mode adaptive suspension system which features an Auto and Sport mode. The car uses a variety of sensors to measure inputs like vehicle speed, steering angle, brake torque, throttle position and acceleration forces to instantly tune the suspension for the given condition depending on what mode is chosen.<ref>https://www.torquenews.com/106/changes-announced-2012-dodge-challenger-srt8-392</ref> In addition, a new heated steering wheel featuring Chrysler's new paddle shifter system, new sport seats, and a 900 watt Harman Kardon audio system became available.<ref>https://www.autoblog.com/buy/2012-Dodge-Challenger/</ref>
===2013 model year=== [[File:2013 Dodge Challenger R T (9453472629) (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|2013 Dodge Challenger R/T]]
For 2013, a Rallye Redline package is available with Dodge Challenger V6 models. Based on the SXT Plus trim, the Rallye Redline package includes unique exterior accents, Black chrome 20-inch wheels with Redline Red accents, performance suspension and brakes, a 3.06 rear-axle ratio and available Radar Red Nappa leather interior.
The Electronic Vehicle Tracking System (EVTS), a GPS-enabled stolen vehicle recovery system became available. {{clear}}
===2014 model year=== The Challenger largely soldiered on with minimal changes for 2014. A new performance package called the "Super Sport Group" was made available for V6 challengers and included the performance-suspension, steering, and brakes from the R/T challengers, a 3.07:1 axle ratio with 215mm rear axle for faster acceleration, rear spoiler, and 20-inch chrome wheels with wider P245/45R20 all-season performance tires. The "Sinister Super Sport pack" was a Super Sport Group but with black wheels instead of chrome. The Challenger SRT8 also gained a launch control system.<ref>https://www.allpar.com/cars/dodge/challenger/challenger-2011.html</ref>
====Dodge Challenger 100th Anniversary Edition==== The 100th Anniversary Edition is a version of 2014 Dodge Challenger SXT Plus with Pentastar V6 engine or R/T Plus with HEMI V8 engine, commemorating the 100th anniversary of brothers Horace Elgin Dodge and John Francis Dodge introducing the Dodge Model 30, with choice of 8 body colors (Pitch Black, Bright White, Billet Silver, Granite Crystal, Ivory Tri-Coat, Phantom Black Tri-Coat, Header Orange and an exclusive High Octane Red pearl), 20x8-inch polished five-spoke aluminum wheels with Granite Crystal pockets, "Dodge Est. 1914" bar-style front-fender badges, Dodge "100" logo on the center caps, a body-color rear spoiler, a red "R/T" heritage grille badge on R/T Plus model, sport seats with all-new Molten Red or Foundry Black Nappa leather upholstery, a custom cloud overprint at sport seats, center console armrest and door armrests; a unique three-spoke flat-bottom performance steering wheel with die-cast paddle shifters, brass-colored accent stitching on leather-wrapped surfaces, Dark Brushed Graphite center console bezels, Liquid Graphite steering-wheel accents, die-cast "Dodge Est. 1914" circular badges on front seatbacks, an embroidered anniversary logo on floor mats, all-new instrument panel cluster graphics (unique black-face gauges with white indication, stand-out red "100" mph indication), Electronic Vehicle Information Center and Uconnect touchscreen Radio with unique startup image, sport mode calibration, performance-tuned suspension, two unique key fobs with 100th Anniversary Edition jeweled logo on the back side, a customized owner's kit, a special commemorative book celebrating the 100 years of Dodge heritage.
The 100th Anniversary Edition was unveiled in the [[LA Auto Show#2013|2013 LA Auto Show]].<ref>{{cite web|first=John |last=Nee |url= http://www.autoblog.com/2013/11/20/dodge-100th-anniversary-edition-charger-challenger-la-2013/ |title=Dodge celebrates big B-day with 100th Anniversary Editions muscle cars |publisher=Autoblog.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-12}}</ref> The car was set to appear in Dodge showrooms during the first quarter of 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://blog.dodge.com/features/dodge-unveils-100th-anniversary-charger-challenger/ |title=Dodge Unveils 100th Anniversary Charger and Challenger |publisher=Blog.dodge.com |date=2013-11-21 |accessdate=2014-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Jeffrey N. |last=Ross |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2013/11/19/dodge-charger-challenger-100th-anniversary-edition/ |title=Dodge celebrates centennial with Charger and Challenger 100th Anniversary Editions |publisher=Autoblog.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-12}}</ref> The Canadian model was set to appear in Dodge showrooms during the first quarter of 2014.<ref>{{cite press release|url= http://media.fcanorthamerica.com/newsrelease.do%3bjsessionid=41B0CF420ABA52926ADDA4933361CC44?&id=15111&mid= |title=Chrysler Canada: Limited-edition Charger and Challenger Models Commemorate 100 Years of Dodge Performance and Heritage |date=20 November 2013 |publisher=Chrysler Canada |accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref>
===2015 model year (facelift)=== {{Multiple image | align = right| direction = vertical | width = 200 |image1 = 2019 Dodge Challenger SXT.jpg |caption1= 2019 Challenger SXT (note the grille's dual snorkels inspired by the 1971 Challenger) |image2 = 2015 Dodge Challenger SRT 392 interior-drivers position.jpg |caption2= 2015 Challenger interior continues the 1971 Challenger theme (SRT 392 depicted) }}
For the 2015 year, changes include:<ref>{{cite press release|url= http://media.chrysler.com/newsrelease.do;jsessionid=3957F907F2D8D0B34AC83CBB3A5BF5C8?&id=15547&mid=169 |title=New 2015 Dodge Challenger Now Offers 485 Best-in-class Horsepower, All-new R/T Scat Pack and 392 HEMI Scat Pack Shaker Models, All-new Interior and Segment-first Standard TorqueFlite Eight-speed Automatic Transmission |publisher=Chrysler |date=17 April 2014 |accessdate=24 February 2015}}</ref> *The high-performance "SRT-8" trim was retired, replaced by '''SRT 392''' and '''SRT Hellcat'''. *5-speed automatic transmission replaced by a new [[ZF 8HP transmission|8-speed ZF 8HP automatic transmission]] *Power output on the 6.4 liter Apache V8 increased by {{cvt|15|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{cvt|5|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} for a total of {{cvt|485|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{cvt|475|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} *A slightly revamped exterior features a new grille with design cues from the 1971 Challenger, Quad LED 'Halo Ring" Head lights, LED Tail lights, and a functional hood intake on HEMI models. *Inside, the Challenger gets a 7-inch (780mm) TFT ([[Thin-film-transistor liquid-crystal display|Thin Film Transistor]]) display with over one hundred possible configurations, 8.4-inch [[Uconnect]] touchscreen radio with available navigation, and a retro styled gauge cluster. *Six-Piston front Brembo brakes with Two-Piece 15.4-Inch Vented/Slotted Rotors and 4-Piston rear Brembo brakes on SRT 392 and SRT Hellcat models.
==== SRT Hellcat ==== {{Multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = 200 |image1 = 2015 HellCat.JPG |caption1= 2015 Challenger SRT Hellcat in custom Stryker Red (VIN# 0001) |image2 = Dodge Challenger, 18 August 2017.jpg |caption2= Dodge Challenger Hellcat on a [[dragstrip]] }}
[[File:Launching sound Challenger.ogg|thumb|left|Hellcat startup sound]]
The Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat is a high performance variant of the Challenger equipped with a supercharged [[Chrysler Hemi engine#Hellcat|6.2-liter HEMI engine]] rated at {{convert|707|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|650|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque. This engine is also available in the [[Dodge Charger (LX)|Dodge Charger]] SRT Hellcat full-sized sedan, the [[Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2)|Jeep Grand Cherokee]] Trackhawk SUV, and as the [[Chrysler Hemi engine|Hellcrate]] engine swap kit. The inner driving light on the left front has been removed to allow air to get into the engine resulting in more torque, and the wheel wells are different from the standard SRT to accommodate the 20-inch aluminum wheels. The SRT Hellcat is equipped with two separate key fobs; use of the "black" fob limits engine output to {{convert|500|hp|abbr=on|0}}, while the "red" fob enables full output capability.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.autoblog.com/2014/07/16/2015-dodge-challenger-srt-hellcat-will-hit-199-mph-burn-1-5-gal/?ncid=txtlnkusaolp00000058 |title=2015 Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat will hit 199 mph |website= Autoblog.com}}</ref> The Hellcat has a quarter mile time of 10.85 seconds; this was accomplished with street legal drag tires. On stock tires the Hellcat was able to achieve 11.2 seconds at {{convert|125|mph|abbr=on}} on the quarter mile.<ref>{{cite web| title= 2015 Dodge Challenger Hellcat|url=http://www.drivesrt.com/2015/challenger-srt-hellcat/|website= DriveSRT.com |publisher=FCA US LLC}}</ref>
The Challenger SRT Hellcat can accelerate from 0–{{convert|60|mph|abbr=on}} in 3.6 seconds and can brake from 60–0 in {{convert|109|ft|0|abbr=on}}. Top speed is {{convert|199|mph|abbr=on}}. The Challenger Hellcat has a lateral acceleration of 0.94 [[g-force|g]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/a15110580/2015-dodge-challenger-srt-hellcat-test-review/|title=2015 Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat|date=2014-08-19|first=Jared|last=Gall|publisher=[[Car and Driver]]|accessdate=2019-10-15}}</ref>
The European-spec Hellcat is capable of accelerating from {{convert|0-62|mph|abbr=on}} in 3.9 seconds, {{convert|0-124|mph|abbr=on}} in 10.7 seconds,<ref>{{cite web| publisher= [[Auto Bild]]| url= http://www.autobild.de/bilder/0-200-km-h---die-40-besten-sprinter-5223217.html#bild71 | title= 0-200 km/h – die 40 besten Sprinter| language= German | access-date= November 9, 2015}}</ref> and {{convert|0-186|mph|abbr=on}} in 38 seconds (although the speedometer appeared to be inaccurate by {{convert|10|–|15|kph|abbr=on|sigfig=1}}).<ref>{{cite web| publisher= Auto Bild Sportscars| title= Dodge Challenger Hellcat - 0-300 km/h Acceleration| url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rr0wH3o6yZM| website= YouTube.com| access-date= November 9, 2015}}</ref>
The Challenger Hellcat was able to complete its [[Gingerman Raceway]] lap in 1:45.8,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.automobilemag.com/features/magazine/1502-camaro-z28-mustang-gt-challenger-hellcat-american-hustle/ |title=American Hustle: Camaro Z/28, Mustang GT, Challenger Hellcat |website= Automobilemag.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-25}}</ref> the [[Hockenheimring|Hockenheim Short]] in 1:14.6,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.a777aa77.ru/2015-dodge-challenger-srt-supercharged-hellcat.php |title=2015 Dodge Challenger SRT Supercharged Hellcat - характеристики, фото, цена |website= A777aa77.ru |date= |accessdate=2016-06-25}}</ref> the [[Road & Track|Motown Mile]] in 0:56.37.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeperfs.com/en/fiche5523-dodge-challenger-srt-hellcat.htm |title=Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat 717 hp - Specs & Performance |website=Zeperfs.com |date=2015-12-24 |accessdate=2016-06-25}}</ref> It also completed the ''[[Motor Trend]]'' figure-8 circuit in 24.7 seconds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fastestlaps.com/models/dodge-challenger-srt-8-hellcat |title=Dodge Challenger SRT-8 Hellcat laptimes, specs, performance data |website=FastestLaps.com |date= |accessdate= 2016-06-25}}</ref> {{clear}}
===2016 model year=== {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 200 |image1= 2016 DodgeChallenger (Texas Dealer special edition) Hellcat side 01.jpg |image2= 2016 DodgeChallenger (Texas Dealer special edition) Hellcat side 02.jpg |footer= 2016 Hellcat (Texas Dealer special edition) }}
In 2016, there were no major changes introduced. Some Texas Dodge Dealers sold a limited edition version of the Hellcat, which were lowered about 2.5 cm in the back, 3 cm in the front, came with an upgraded supercharger which was dynamometer tested at between {{Convert|745 and 750|hp|0|abbr=on}} (readouts were packaged with the autos), featured 305/35 20 rear-wheel tires, and all vehicles were backed by a standard factory warranty. Most were white with black Carbon-fiber 'rally stripes', but a small number were red, with black carbon-fiber stripes. The upgraded models were 'sticker priced' at about $80,000. The program was terminated by Dodge, who announced the 2017 Challenger Hellcat with upgraded performance, and began work on The Demon model (which was not available for sale until the 2018 model year).
===2017 model year=== [[File:2017 Challenger GT in Graphite Crystal.jpg|thumb|left|2017 Challenger GT in Graphite Crystal. Note the higher stance of the Pursuit-based suspension.]] For the 2017 model year, a GT model was introduced with an [[all-wheel drive]] (AWD) version of the SXT Plus.<ref name="GT AWD">[http://autoweek.com/article/car-reviews/2017-dodge-challenger-gt-first-drive-sacrilege-feels-right 2017 Dodge Challenger GT First Drive], autoweek.com, dated 30 January 2017, last accessed 2 December 2017</ref> The Challenger GT uses the same AWD system and suspension as the [[Dodge Charger (LX)#2014 Dodge Charger Pursuit.2C Charger Pursuit V-8 AWD|Dodge Charger Pursuit]]. It is available exclusively with the 3.6-Liter V6 Pentastar engine and the 8-speed automatic transmission.
The AWD system includes both an active transfer case and front-axle disconnect system. The system defaults to rear-wheel drive (RWD) but can seamlessly transition between RWD and AWD if certain conditions are met, like low external temperature, rainfall, or loss of traction. No driver input is required.<ref name="2017 Model Year">[http://www.dodge.com/2017/challenger/safety-security/index.html 2017 Dodge Challenger, Safety and Security, Advanced All-Wheel Drive], dodge.com, last accessed 17 December 2016</ref> In Sport Mode, the car uses AWD exclusively. The AWD system in the Challenger GT is configured to be rear-biased (applies more power to the rear wheels). Only up to 38% of power is transferred to the front wheels.
Other model additions include the 5.7-liter V8 equipped T/A and 6.4-liter V8 equipped T/A 392 models. T/A models include a black painted hood with center air intake, black roof, black decklid, bodyside graphics, a cold-air induction system through the front head lamps similar to that used in the Challenger SRT Hellcat, Houndstooth cloth performance seats, and white-faced gauges. T/A 392 models include everything on T/A models in addition to the more powerful 6.4 L V8, six-piston front Brembo brakes with two-piece 15.4-inch vented/slotted rotors and 4-piston rear Brembo brakes, and 20x9.5-inch wheels with 275/40ZR20 tires. Every Challenger gains an updated Uconnect infotainment system; the optional 8.4-inch touchscreen with navigation adds multitouch gestures.
Models equipped with the 5.7-liter V8 now have an electronically controlled low-restriction active exhaust for a more aggressive exhaust note. Among the other additions are standard Houndstooth cloth seats on some models and revised paint choices. Green Go, Yellow Jacket, Destroyer Grey, and Octane Red are new colors, while White Knuckle and Contusion Blue are renamed carryovers.<ref name="caranddriver.com">https://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2018-dodge-challenger-in-depth-model-review</ref>
=== 2018 model year ===
Minor changes were made for the 2018 model year. For SXT and R/T models equipped with the 3.6-liter V6 and 5.7-liter V8, an all new Performance Handling Group package is available. This package adds 4-piston black Brembo brakes (a $500 option for red brake calipers is optional) in the front along with a Bilstein performance suspension, 20x9 inch wheels with 245/45ZR20 performance tires, and upgraded steering. The Challenger GT gains a new 19-inch wheel option while SXT Plus and R/T Plus trims equipped with the Super Trak package come with nappa leather and microsuede sport seats. The SXT, R/T, R/T Shaker, and T/A models receive a standard 7.0-inch Uconnect touchscreen. A backup camera is now standard. For exterior colors, new additions include F8 Green, IndiGO Blue, B5 Blue and Plum Crazy.<ref name="caranddriver.com"/>
====SRT Demon==== {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 200 |image1= Dodge Challenger Demon 1 Genf 2018.jpg |image2= Dodge Challenger Demon Back Genf 2018.jpg |footer= Dodge Challenger Demon at the [[Geneva Motor Show#2018|2018 Geneva Motor Show]] }}
The Demon is a limited production wide body and extreme ([[Drag racing|drag race]] level) performance variant of the already high performance Challenger SRT Hellcat. It debuted as the fastest and most powerful production car in the world<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.topgear.com/car-news/top-gear-series-25/heres-everything-you-need-to-know-about-dodge-demon|title=Everything you need to know about the Dodge Demon|last=|first=|date=2018-03-19|website=BBC Top Gear|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref><ref>[https://www.canberratimes.com.au/story/6001372/lifestyles-of-the-rich-and-the-famous-kyrgios-new-300k-toy/ "Lifestyles of the rich and the famous" --''Canberra Times'']</ref> during the [[New York Auto Show#2017|New York Auto Show]] in April 2017.<ref>http://media.fcanorthamerica.com/newsrelease.do?id=18158&mid=1</ref>
The Demon uses an all-new 6.2-liter V8 engine equipped with a 2.7-liter [[supercharger]], which is rated at {{convert|808|hp|kW PS|abbr=on}} with 91 [[octane]] gasoline and {{Convert|840|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} with 100 octane fuel or higher (both outputs are with the red key fob supplied with the car). Torque stands at {{Convert|770|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} on 100 octane fuel. The car weighs {{Convert|215|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} less than the Hellcat, the total being {{Convert|4254|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}}. The SRT Demon uses a set of road tires by [[Toyo Tire & Rubber Company|Nitto Tire]], called the NT05R. The tires are the 315/40R18 variations at both front and rear. The tires are targeted for the drag strip, but have enough tread pattern to make them legal for the road. This tire, although an NT05R consumer tire, is a variation built specifically to withstand the power output of the Demon. This makes the Challenger SRT Demon the first production car to contain a set of drag radial road tires.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.nydailynews.com/autos/news/dodge-challenger-demon-record-wide-drag-racing-tires-article-1.2956247 |title=Dodge’s Challenger Demon gets record-wide drag racing tires|publisher=NYDailyNews |access-date=2017-04-14}}</ref> The SRT Demon contains a system that is used specifically for drag racing called [[transbrake]], which is a mechanism that puts the transmission in 1st gear and the reverse gear simultaneously, holding the Demon stationary.<ref name="Dodge Demon 1"/> This is used along with the car's [[torque converter]] to build up hydraulic pressure before launch.
The power-to-weight ratio of the SRT Demon is {{convert|418|hp|kW PS|abbr=on|0}} per ton on 91 octane gasoline and {{convert|435|hp|kW PS|abbr=on|0}} per ton on 100 octane or higher.
The SRT Demon accelerates from {{Convert|0-30|mph|kph|0|abbr=on}} in 1.0 second, {{Convert|0-60|mph|kph|0|abbr=on}} in 2.3 seconds (2.0s with a rollout), {{Convert|0-100|mph|kph|0|abbr=on}} in 5.1 seconds, a top speed of {{Convert|168|mph|kph|abbr=on}} (factory limited), and the quarter mile (400 m) in only 9.65 seconds at {{Convert|140.09|mph|kph|abbr=on}}.<ref>http://www.hotrod.com/articles/2018-dodge-challenger-srt-demon-runs-9s-makes-840-hp/</ref> This makes the Demon the [[List of fastest production cars by acceleration|fastest non-electric]] production car to reach 0-60 mph (0–97 km/h) and to complete a straight-line quarter mile at its time of announcement. The SRT Demon is also capable of accelerating at 1.8 G's of force at launch, making this the hardest launching production car.<ref>{{Citation|last=Dodge|title=Demon Unleashed {{!}} Challenger SRT® Demon {{!}} Dodge|date=2017-04-11 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3vD6A6NxySQ |accessdate=2017-04-14}}</ref> The boost pressure of the supercharger can be increased to 14.5 psi and redline up to 6,500 rpm. With this extreme power, and hard acceleration, the SRT Demon is the first production car to perform a [[wheelie]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.autoblog.com/amp/2017/04/11/the-840-horsepower-2018-dodge-challenger-srt-demon-has-arrived/ |title=Inner Demon revealed: 840 hp and other jaw-dropping details|publisher=AutoBlog |access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref> With the control module from the "Demon Crate" and high-speed tires, the Demon has attained a top speed of over {{convert|200|mph|kph|abbr=on}} in test runs.<ref>https://www.roadandtrack.com/new-cars/a27031798/dodge-challenger-srt-demon-top-speed-211-mph/</ref>
Because of the lack of an NHRA certified roll cage, which is required if the quarter mile time is under 10 seconds, the [[National Hot Rod Association|NHRA]] banned the SRT Demon from competition.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.roadandtrack.com/car-shows/new-york-auto-show/news/a33207/how-you-can-drag-race-the-demon-despite-the-nhra-ban/ |title=How You Can Drag Race the Demon Despite the NHRA Ban |author=Sorokanich, Bob |magazine=[[Road & Track]] |date=12 April 2017 |accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref>
Like the SRT Hellcat, it comes with both red and black key fobs, with the black fob limiting the power output to {{convert|500|hp|0|abbr=on}}. With the red key and the use of 100+ octane gasoline, the Demon can utilize its full power potential. Only 3,300 cars were made, with production beginning in the summer of 2017 and market introduction happening in the fall of 2017.<ref name="DODGEdemon">{{cite web|title=2018 Dodge Demon - Domestic. Not Domesticated. #ifyouknowyouknow|url=http://www.dodge.com/en/ifyouknowyouknow/#|publisher=[[Dodge]]|accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="MAdemon">{{cite web|title=2018 Dodge Demon delivers 840 horsepower, does 0-60 in 2.3 seconds|url=http://www.motorauthority.com/news/1109826_2018-dodge-demon-delivers-840-horsepower-does-0-60-in-2-3-seconds|website=[[Motor Authority]]|accessdate=12 April 2017|language=en}}</ref>
The interior of the SRT Demon is the same as all other Challenger trims, but with changes that differentiate it to the other trims. The Demon only includes a front driver's seat as standard, and no other seats front or rear in the vehicle. However, the front passenger's seat, as well as a rear bench seat, can both be added back as options for one dollar each. To replace the rear seats, Dodge included rear roll bars, and has a 4-point harness installed on it for the driver seat.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://st.automobilemag.com/uploads/sites/11/2017/04/2018-Dodge-Challenger-SRT-Demon-interior-bars.jpg |title=Dodge Challenger SRT Demon (Interior Bars)|publisher=AutomobileMag|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref> The dashboard display and the seats now have the Demon logo on them,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tflcar.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/2018-dodge-demon-srt-interior-1024x682.jpg |title=Dodge Challenger SRT Demon (Interior w/ Demon Logo)|publisher=TFLcar |access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.caricos.com/cars/d/dodge/2018_dodge_challenger_srt_demon/2560x1440/99.html |title=2018 Dodge Challenger SRT Demon (Photo #99)|publisher=Caricos |access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref> and includes a performance display on it, as well as on the center console touch screen.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xEno4uHvHXg |title=Performance Pages - Challenger SRT® Demon - Dodge|publisher=YouTube (Dodge)|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref>
The following list below is a breakdown of how [[Dodge]] engineers reduced the [[curb weight]] of the 2018 Challenger SRT Demon to {{Convert|1,930|kg|lbs|0|abbr=on}} over the {{Convert|2,027|kg|lbs|0|abbr=on}} [[curb weight]] of the SRT Hellcat, a difference of {{Convert|98|kg|lbs|0|abbr=on}}:<ref name="demon-media">{{cite web|url=https://iimediaevents.com/dodgechallengerdemon/|title=Dodge Demon Launch|publisher=Dodge|accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://carbuzz.com/news/the-2018-dodge-challenger-demon-s-weight-loss-is-totally-insane|title=The 2018 Dodge Challenger Demon's Weight Loss Is Totally Insane|publisher=Car Buzz|accessdate=18 March 2018}}</ref>
* Removed front passenger seat and passenger seatbelt ({{Convert|-58|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease; seats available at a dollar)<ref name="Dodge Demon 1" /> * Removed rear bench seat, seatbelts, restraints, and front and rear floor mats ({{Convert|-55|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease) * Removed 16 [[Harman Kardon]] audio speakers, factory [[subwoofer]], [[amplifier]], and all [[electrical wiring]] ({{Convert|-24|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease) * Removed rear trunk deck lid cover trim, trunk carpeting, and spare tire cover ({{Convert|-20|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease) * Used smaller, hollower front and rear sway bars ({{Convert|-19|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease) * Removed [[Adhesive|mastic]], body deadeners, [[Insulator (electricity)|insulators]], and foam ({{Convert|-18|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease) * Used lightweight, all-aluminum four-piston front and rear [[brake caliper]]s and {{Convert|360|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} front and rear two-piece brake rotors ({{Convert|-16|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease) * Installed lightweight aluminum front and rear [[alloy]] wheels and open-ended front and rear wheel [[lug nut]]s ({{Convert|-16|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease) * Replaced power-tilting and telescoping steering column with manually-tilting and telescoping steering column ({{Convert|-4|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease) * Removed front and rear ParkSense [[parking sensor]]s and ParkSense front and rear park sensor [[Modular design|module]] ({{Convert|-2|lbs|kg|0|abbr=on}} decrease)

==== Discontinuation ==== The last SRT Demon rolled off the assembly line in Brampton, Ontario, Canada on May 31, 2018. It was sold at a Barrett-Jackson auction in June 2018 alongside the final Dodge Viper.
=== 2019 model year === For the 2019 model year, Dodge released new high performance versions of the challenger, trimmed the line-up down to six models, and made numerous other tweaks and changes. The model line-up for 2019 includes the following trims: SXT, GT, R/T, R/T Scat Pack, SRT Hellcat, and SRT Hellcat Redeye. Both SXT and GT models are now available in both rear and all wheel drive, with the GT previously having been the only model available in AWD. GTs gain a more aggressive look with a performance hood, front splitter, steering and suspension while maintaining the optional performance handling group which includes wider wheels, performance summer tires, 4-piston Brembo brakes, and fixed-rate Bilstein suspension. The SXT model loses the performance handling group as an option, lacks the more aggressive exterior upgrades of the GT and has less aggressive gearing, making it the cheaper economical alternative. R/T Scat Pack models come with a new power-bulge aluminum hood standard. Shared with the SRT Hellcat, this hood features dual air extractors that cool the engine and help reduce lift. For 5.7L and 6.4L V8 R/T models, the rear seats can be deleted at the cost of $1 and have a net weight savings of 55 lbs. In addition, a second level of the performance handling group called the "performance plus package" is offered, providing 20-Inch x 9.5-inch low-gloss black forged wheels, 275/40ZR20 Pirelli P Zero summer tires, and a limited slip differential in addition to the upgrades found in the performance handling group which remains unchanged since its introduction in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.fcanorthamerica.com/newsrelease.do?id=19971&mid= |title=Press Kit: 2019 Dodge Challenger and Challenger SRT |publisher=[[FCA US]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2019}}</ref>
'''SRT Hellcat:''' A slight increase in power is present for 2019, with horsepower rising to 717 and torque to 656 lb-ft. A new dual snorkel hood is introduced. Additionally, the 2019 model's starting price is more than $5,500 lower compared to the 2018 model. A 6-speed Tremec manual and ZF 8-speed automatic remain the sole transmission options.
[[File:2019 Dodge Challenger Hellcat Redeye (2), Cleveland Auto Show.jpg|thumb|2019 Challenger Hellcat Redeye at the Cleveland Auto Show]]
'''SRT Hellcat Redeye:''' Following the discontinuation of the Demon, the Redeye was developed to fill the void. Essentially a heavily upgraded Hellcat, the Redeye is equipped with a slightly less powerful (due to a smaller hood intake system) Demon engine: a supercharged 6.2L V8 rated at {{convert|797|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|707|lbft|0|abbr=on}} of torque, an increase of {{convert|90|hp|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|11|lbft|0|abbr=on}} over the standard Hellcat motor. Other upgrades include reinforced ZF 8 speed automatic transmission, track-tuned suspension, Torque Reserve and 41-Spline Heavy-Duty Half-Shafts, SRT Power Chiller® and After-Run Chiller.
'''Scat Pack 1320 Package:''' Equipped with the 6.4L [[Chrysler Hemi Engine]] rated at {{convert|485|hp|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|475|lbft|0|abbr=on}}, the Scat Pack 1320 adds 20-Inch x 9.5-Inch Low Gloss Black Drag Wheels, 275/40R20 102W drag radial tires, adaptive damping suspension, SRT-tuned drag suspension, air catcher headlamps, deletion of front and rear passenger seats, a special speed limited engine controller, extreme-duty 41-spline half shafts and a trans-brake. Specially developed Nexen 275/40R20l street-legal drag radial tires are available for better grip.
The Dodge Challenger R/T Scat Pack 1320 can be modified for NHRA competition in accordance with Stock and Super Stock class rules. It will feature a class weight break of 8.72 and carry a minimum weight of 3,400 pounds. Contestants intending to compete at an NHRA event must meet all regulations for the category entered.<ref>https://www.dodgegarage.com/news/article/product/2019/04/licensed-to-drag.html</ref>
'''Widebody Package:''' For the 2019 model year, buyers can order the Challenger Scat Pack, SRT Hellcat, and SRT Hellcat Redeye with the "Widebody Package".<ref>https://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/challenger/2019/2019-dodge-challenger-rt-scat-pack-392-widebody-hellcat-redeye-first-drive-review/</ref> When purchased, the challenger gains the following: * Widebody fender flares * 20x11 Devils Rim forged aluminum wheels * 305/35ZR20 Pirelli 3-season performance (P Zero Nero All Season) tires * 3-mode Bilstein adaptive damping suspension uniquely tuned for competition use * 6-piston calipers with 15.4 inch vented and slotted rotors in the front (standard on Hellcat and hellcat Redeye models) * Stiffened anti-roll bars sized 34mm in front and 22mm rear (standard on Hellcat and hellcat Redeye models)
=== Limited production 3rd party variants === In addition to official Dodge concept cars, there have been numerous limited production and street legal variants created by third parties, based on stock cars that have been rebuilt with modified powertrains, suspensions, and interiors. These include the SMS 570 and (supercharged) 570X with up to a claimed {{convert|700|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, the Mr. Norm's Challengers with a claimed {{convert|637|or|900|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} horsepower, the supercharged SpeedFactory SF600R with around {{convert|600|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, the supercharged Richard Petty Signature Series with a claimed {{convert|610|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, and the Legacy by Petty Convertible Challenger completely customized by Petty's Garage to include a one of a kind front end and NASCAR styled treatments.<ref>[https://www.google.com/search?q=legacy+by+petty+convertible+challenger&rls=com.microsoft:en-US:IE-SearchBox&biw=1088&bih=498&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=u7eKVdSpOMut-AHB4azoBA&ved=0CCgQ7Ak#imgrc=HO5GF4553DUJtM%253A%3BtVN-ZF3NM1ekrM%3Bhttp%253A%252F%252Fcarphotos.cardomain.com%252Fstory_images%252F1%252F2673%252F3821%252F6681910003_large.jpg%3Bhttp%253A%252F%252Fautoholics.com%252F2012%252F10%252F30%252F-Richard-Petty-Challenger-Convertible-668191%3B900%3B599 Legacy by Petty Convertible Challenger]</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allpar.com/cars/dodge/challenger/special-cars.html | title=Special 2009–2011 Dodge Challenger cars |publisher=allpar.com | accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> Every year a handful (12 or less) of Challenger convertibles are created by various conversion companies. The cars cost close to $100,000.

==Racing== [[File:NationwideCOT2010NMPA.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Early version of the Nationwide Series Challenger R/T]] [[File:Challenger Sebring.jpg|thumb|2017 Trans Am TA class Challenger at Sebring]]
The Challenger was introduced to the SCCA [[Trans Am Series]] in 1970. Two factory-backed cars were prepared by Ray Caldwell's Autodynamics and driven by [[Sam Posey]] and [[Tony Adamowicz]]. The No.77 car was built at Autodynamics from a street Challenger T/A that was taken from a local dealer showroom. The No.76 chassis arrived mid-season from Dan Gurney's All-American Racers, and was completed by Autodynamics. * Dodge's early to mid-1970s factory-supported "Kit Car" program for short-track late-model stock car racing offered a choice of Challenger, and a few (less than 12) were made, but in 1974 Dodge ended the Challenger line and they went to the Dodge Dart Sports and Dodge Aspen bodies over a steel-tube chassis.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.superbirdclub.com/earnhardtkitcar.html |title=Dale Earnhardt Tests the Chrysler Kit Car |publisher=superbirdclub.com |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> * Blackforest Motorsports has currently entered a Challenger in the [[Continental Challenge]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.grand-am.com/schedule/entrylist.cfm?series=k&eid=1502 |title=Event Information – Entry List |publisher=Grand-am.com |date=January 10, 2010 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110811062836/http://www.grand-am.com/schedule/entrylist.cfm?series=k&eid=1502 |archivedate=August 11, 2011 |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> * The Challenger R/T has been used as the Chrysler model for starting in [[2010 NASCAR Nationwide Series]] competition.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://nationwide.nascar.com/nationwide-series/2010/news/headlines/bg/07/01/nationwide.new.car.ford.mustang.dodge.challenger.nascar.roots/ |title=Dodge, Ford hope new cars mark return to NASCAR roots |publisher=Nascar.com |date=July 1, 2010 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100704043626/http://nationwide.nascar.com/nationwide-series/2010/news/headlines/bg/07/01/nationwide.new.car.ford.mustang.dodge.challenger.nascar.roots |archivedate=July 4, 2010 |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref>
With Dodge officially out of NASCAR at the end of the 2012 season, the remaining cars and racing parts have been bought up by "privateer" racing teams and continue to show up in [[Nationwide Series]] during the 2013 and 2014 seasons. [[J. J. Yeley]] indicated his two-car team would continue to field a Challenger in the series for as long as he can find parts to keep the cars running. The team stopped after the 2014 season after his No. 93 (later No. 28) regularly ran in the top-20 during races, though the [[Mike Harmon]]-owned No. 74 and the [[Derek White (racing driver)|Derek White]]-operated No. 40 qualified and ran Dodges in 2015. [[Mike Harmon Racing]] ran a Dodge the entire season and also did so in 2016, and has raced in over half of the 2017 season so far. Likewise, White's [[MBM Motorsports]] team fielded the Nos. 13 and 40 as Dodges in some races.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jayski.com/news/nxs/2016/story/_/page/2016nxs-teamchart|title=2016 NASCAR XFINITY Series Team Chart|work=[[Jayski's Silly Season Site]]|accessdate=March 22, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202034351/http://www.jayski.com/news/nxs/2016/story/_/page/2016nxs-teamchart|archive-date=December 2, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> MBM continues to field Dodges into 2018 with Timmy Hill in the 66 (was the 13).
In late 2014 two Challengers fielded by Miller Racing with the support of SRT and [[Mopar]] driven by Cameron Lawrence and Joe Stevens started racing in the [[Trans-Am Series]]'s TA2 class. Both cars used a spec Howe road racing tube chassis with fiberglass bodies. Powered by a Hemi 392 slightly modified for road racing extremes and restricted by class rules, the cars made around 500 horsepower. Except for slightly bulged fenders and large rear wing, the cars look very much like the stock/street version, despite being roughly 7/8s the size of the road car. Lawrence won four of 12 races in the 2015 season, finishing third overall in the Trans Am TA2 championship. Joe Stevens in the No. 11 "Green Car" finished sixth overall after a fourth place at the season finale at Daytona International Speedway. Joe Stevens also received the Cool Shirt Hard Charger award for his excellent rookie season performance. For the 2016 season, the Stevens-Miller Team fielded three Challengers in the TA2 series and ran in 16 events, scoring a few wins. The No. 77 car was painted in a throw-back paint scheme very similar to the 1970 No. 77 car driven by [[Sam Posey]]. The No. 12 car occasionally fielded a blue scheme paying tribute to the Plymouth Cuda Trans-Am car driven by [[Swede Savage]].
In March 2017 the Challenger returned to the TA class in Trans-Am at Sebring after a nearly 40-year absence from Trans-Am's fastest class of racing. It was driven by Jeff Hinkle under the American V8 Road Racing team with John Debenedictis as crew chief. The car was orange and purple with stripes of many of the other challenger colors to celebrate the current stable of street cars. It is powered by a Penske Engines Mopar R5 / P7 carburated motor producing {{convert|855|hp|0|abbr=on}}. In its debut it qualified 16th and finished 9th out of a field of 24.
At all [[Superbike World Championship]] races held in the United States, Fiat's Alfa Romeo safety car is replaced with Chrysler's Dodge Challenger.

''[[Detroit Diesel]]'' units |wheelbase = {{convert|121|-|212|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} The '''Dodge LCF''' (for "'''L'''ow '''C'''ab '''F'''orward") was a series of medium- and heavy-duty trucks built by [[Dodge]] from 1960 until 1976. They replaced the [[Dodge Forward Look]] range of [[cabover]] trucks built in the fifties. The 500 through 700 series were medium duty only, while 800 through 1000 series were reserved for heavy-duty versions. LCF range was also sold in Canada with the [[Fargo Trucks|Fargo]] badge.{{cite web | last = Wickstead | first = Kris | title = Dodge Big Rigs | url = http://www.sweptline.com/hist/bigtrucks.html | work = The '61–'71 Dodge Truck Website | publisher = Sweptline.com | accessdate = 2011-08-23 }} In addition, following [[Chrysler Corporation]] policy of [[Rebadging|badge engineering]] to provide a greater number of sales outlets overseas, LCFs were also marketed in some countries with the [[De Soto (automobile)|De Soto]] badge. LCF cabin section was taken directly from the 1956–1960 [[Dodge C series|range of Dodge pickup trucks]], with its panoramic windshield, but was fitted with a unique front section. One of the Dodge LCF's main selling points was accessibility; the sides of the engine compartment and fenders being arranged to swing open. A mechanic could easily stand between the engine and the front wheel while working.{{cite web | first = Kyle | last = Youngblood | title = Dodge LCF/HCF | url = http://www.olddodges.com/cseries.htm | accessdate = 2011-08-23 | work = Dodge Trucks of the 60's and 70's }} A range of Dodge and [[International Harvester]] gasoline engines were available, as were diesels from [[Perkins Engines|Perkins]] (for lighter variants), [[Cummins]], [[Caterpillar Inc|Caterpillar]], and [[Detroit Diesel]] for the heaviest duty versions, both [[Straight-six engine|six-cylinder]] and V8 versions. Gasoline-powered versions were simply called the "C" series, followed by a numeral indicating weight class, and all of them were [[V8 engine|V8]]-powered. Perkins diesel-engined units were called "PC", while inline diesels were called "CN" and V-type diesels were "CV". A "T" following the letters indicates a tandem rear axle. On LCFs equipped with inline-six [[Diesel engine|diesels]] the engine intruded into the cabin. This was covered with a removable panel for maintenance. A near unlimited range of engines, transmissions, and rear axles were available for what was usually a built-to-order truck. The biggest diesel available was the Cummins V-903, a giant {{convert|14794|cc|cid|0|disp=flip|abbr=on}} unit with a modest {{convert|289|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} max output. The smaller {{convert|9299|cc|cid|0|disp=flip|abbr=on}} [[Detroit Diesel Series 71|Detroit Diesel 8V-71N]] was the most powerful engine, with {{convert|300|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} on tap.{{ citation | title = Dodge Trucks: Heavy-Duty LCF Diesel Models | publisher = Chrysler Motors Corporation |date=September 1972 | url = http://www.olddodges.com/literature/cseries/cnt900-1.jpg }} With Dodge pulling out of the heavy truck business, the C series' last year in the US market was 1975. A few hundred more CNT800's and CNT900's were exported in 1976 as [[Complete knock down|CKD kits]] to Latin American countries, where the last units were assembled until 1978. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Dodge Truck Timeline}} [[Category:Trucks]] [[Category:Dodge vehicles|LCF]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Vehicles introduced in 1960]]

The '''Banks Sidewinder''' is a [[land speed record]] vehicle that was built by [[Gale Banks Engineering]] in 2001. Based on a [[Dodge Dakota]] [[pickup truck]], the Banks Sidewinder became the fastest pickup ever when it set a speed record of {{convert|213.583|mph|km/h|3|abbr=on}} at [[Bonneville Salt Flats|Bonneville]] in October 2001.
==Sidewinder Dodge Dakota Pickup== One of the fastest roadgoing vehicles, the Gale Banks Built [[Dodge Dakota]] has broken many speed and quarter mile records and is used as the shop truck for Gale Banks own company.
===Overview===
In 2002, a 5.9 L [[Cummins]] diesel-powered pickup, modified by [[Gale Banks]] and his company [[Gale Banks Engineering]] set an [[FIA]]-certified [[land speed record]] at the [[Bonneville Salt Flats]] with a one-way pass of 222-mph and a combined two-way speed of 217-mph. This record-breaking and street-legal vehicle was driven on the highway to Bonneville from [[Southern California]] and pulled its own service trailer, defying the modern racing tradition of competition vehicles being transported via trailer for legality and vehicle wear-and-tear reasons. During this trip, the Sidewinder Dakota achieved fuel economy figures of 23.6-mpg while in highway driving trim.
===Modifications=== Starting with a stock 5.9L Cummins straight-six engine that produced approximately 393-horsepower, Gale Banks Engineering extensively modified the engine, adding a variable geometry (VGT) [[Holset Engineering|Holset]] turbocharger, water-cooled intercooler, and six-speed transmission from [[New Venture Gear]]. The [[Dodge]] Dakota’s firewall was moved back approximately 18-inches to accommodate the new high performance engine, which now tested on the dyno at 735-horsepower with 1300 lb-ft of torque.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bankspower.com/magazines/show/513-Banks-Sidewinder-The-Worlds-Fastest-Pickup |title=Banks Sidewinder: The World's Fastest Pickup! |publisher=PickupTruck.com |date=February 2003 |accessdate=12 July 2015}}</ref> 300-mph speed-rated tires were also added to safely get the power to the ground.
===Summary=== The Gale Banks Engineering Cummins-powered Dodge Dakota is the world’s-fastest diesel or gasoline-powered pickup truck and still holds the [[FIA]] record as of late 2009. It is currently on display at the NHRA Museum [[National Hot Rod Association]] as part of their "Gale Banks: The First 50 Years" temporary exhibit.
