W-398-QM-11592 | T-215 || 77 || Emergency Repair, chassis || 77 || WC-41 || Emergency Repair, cab & chassis || 77 || Emergency Repair, chassis |} ==Descriptions — Three-quarter-ton models== [[File:Dodge WC-55 M6 Gun Motor Carriage Top schematic from TM9-808.jpg|thumb|Top view of WC-55 (a version of the {{nobr|WC-51}} / {{nobr|WC-52}}) shows the squat, short and wide stance, proportions of the revised {{3/4}}-ton Dodges]] In 1942, the Dodge WC range was significantly revised. All four wheeled models were uprated to a nominal three-quarter ton payload rating, and in 1943 a 1{{1/2}}-ton six-wheel drive variant was derived (see appropriate section). All models were widened to a {{convert|64+3/4|in|cm|abbr=on}} front and rear track, while at the same time the bulk of production (pick-up / weapons carrier and radio / command reconnaissance) models were significantly shortened, from a {{convert|116|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} to a {{convert|98|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} wheelbase, giving the vehicles much more squat proportions. Ambulances, carry-alls, and telephone installation / emergency repair trucks received a wheelbase reduction of only {{convert|2|in|cm|0|abbr=off}}. Panel vans were dropped from the range and no longer made. The volume production pick-up / weapons carrier models received a redesigned rear bed, seating troops on top of the rear wheels, instead of between them, further widening these models to 6 ft 11 in / 2.11 meters. A single such unit, though compact, offered practical all-terrain transportation to a full eight man rifle squad and their gear.
The {{3/4}}-tons retained the same 6-cylinder in-line, L-head engine of 92 hp (73 kW) gross, from the {{1/2}}-ton WC series. ==={{3/4}}-ton Ambulances=== '''WC-54''' [[File:Dodge WC54 Field Ambulance (1943) (owner Glen Rummery) pic4.JPG|thumb|1943 WC-54 Ambulance]] {{main|Dodge WC54}} The WC-54 Truck, 3/4 ton, 4x4 Ambulance, Dodge (G502), was produced as an ambulance, but a few were modified to serve as radio/telephone trucks with the [[US Signal Corps]]. A total of 26,002 {{nobr|WC-54}} units were built from 1942 through 1944, after which the ambulance was redesigned, and replaced by the {{nobr|WC-64}} in 1945.{{sfnp|ref=SRATAM4045|Summary Report – Tank-Automotive Materiel|1945|page=62}}{{cite magazine |last=Benedict |first=Chris |date=July 1979 |title=Dodge 3/4 Ton 4X4 And 1½ Ton 6X6 Production, 1942–1945 |magazine=Army Motors magazine |location= |publisher= }} *''Length'': 16 ft 3 in / 4,95 m *''Height'': 7 ft 6 in / 2,30 m *''Weight'': 5,920 lb / 2 685 kg *''Width'': 6 ft 6 in / 1,98 m *''Payload'': 1,800 lb / 816 kg [[File:DodgeWC64 OpendagLandmacht2008.JPG|thumb|Dodge WC-64 Ambulance]] '''WC-64''' The WC-64 KD Truck, 3/4 ton, 4x4 Ambulance Dodge (G502) was an ambulance based on the same chassis as the {{nobr|WC-54}} but with a knock-down body designed to increase the number of vehicles that could be shipped at the same time. The rear boxes were supplied in two major parts: lower and upper. The lower part of the box was attached to the chassis at the factory, while the upper box was crated for installation in the field.[http://www.wc64.com/technical.htm Dodge {{nobr|WC-64 KD}} Ambulance – Technical] 3,500 Knock-down ambulances were built between the beginning of 1945 and the end of the war,{{cite web|url=http://www.pinodesign.nl/dodge/history.htm |title=History |publisher=Pinodesign.nl |date= |accessdate=2013-06-06}} the great majority (2,531 units) went to allies under lend-lease: {{cite report |author=U.S. Ordnance Corps |author-link=Ordnance Corps (United States Army) |date=31 December 1946 |title=Quantities of Lend-Lease Shipments |section= III-B "Ordnance - Motor Transport Vehicles", Part I |url=https://lend-lease.net/files/Part_3B_pages_1-27.pdf |publisher=[[United States Department of War|U.S. War Department]] |page=1 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20181231194330/http://lend-lease.airforce.ru/documents/files/Part_3B_pages_1-27.pdf |archivedate=2018-12-31 |url-status=live |access-date=17 June 2019 }} * 1,123 to the free French forces * 644 to Great Britain * 475 to China * 149 to Brazil and 82 to other Latin American republics ==={{3/4}}-ton Carry-all=== {{multiple image |direction=vertical |width=220 |header=WC-53 Carry-all |image1=Dodge WC 53 Carryall W-20166121 S pic1 (cropped).JPG |caption1= |image2=BNDL-G502Late-2 from SNL G-657 (cropped).jpg |caption2=Split tailgate shown on rear }} '''WC-53''' A carryall, mechanically it was virtually identical to the [[Dodge WC54|{{nobr|WC-54}}]] but was fitted with a body which was the 1939 civilian carryall modified to military specifications. All four rear side windows were opening wind-up and the seating consisted of front folding passenger seat to allow rear access, two person second row leaving space to access to the rear full width three person seat. The spare was carried on a mount on the driver's side and although the door was fully operational it could not be opened (driver had to enter from passenger side). The rear end had split tailgates.[https://bringatrailer.com/2010/09/09/1942-dodge-power-wagon-wc-53-carryall/ 1942 Dodge Power Wagon {{nobr|WC-53}} Carryall – Bring a Trailer]{{sfnp|ref=SNL_G657|SNL G-657 Master Parts List|1943|loc=[https://cdn3.volusion.com/hrqpw.cruld/v/vspfiles/photos/BNDL-G502Late-2.jpg?1549907996 page 381]}}
WC-53s were also fitted as radio trucks with a bench on the left side with the operator seated sideways. 8,400 {{nobr|WC-53}}: Truck, 3/4 ton, 4x4 Dodge Carryall (G502) were built. No carryalls came from the factory with a winch, though there was a field modification available.DODGE: Cinq generations de tous terrains – Boniface and Jeudy (in French)
*''Length'': 15 ft 6 in / 4,73 m *''Width'': 6 ft 7 in / 2,00 m *''Height'': 6 ft 9 in / 2,06 m *''Weight'': 5,700 lb / 2 590 kg *''Payload'': 1,750 lb / 800 kg ==={{3/4}}-ton (Radio) Command Reconnaissance=== '''WC-56''' [[File:Dodge WC 56 Command Car (1).jpg|thumb|Rear of command car, desert tan]] [[File:Dodge at Sinsheim photo-1.JPG|thumb|The WC-56 was wider and much shorter than the {{1/2}}-ton command cars, giving it squat proportions.]] The WC-56 Truck, Command Reconnaissance, 3/4 ton, 4x4 w/o Winch Dodge (G502) was a command and reconnaissance vehicle akin to a large Willys Jeep. It did not prove popular as it was heavier and not as maneuverable as the Jeep, and its distinctive profile made it a target. The soft-top included side-curtains, for better weather shielding. 21,156 units were built.{{sfnp|ref=SRATAM4045|Summary Report – Tank-Automotive Materiel|1945|page=63}} *''Length'': 13 ft 10 in / 4,22 m *''Width'': 6 ft 7 in / 2,00 m *''Height'': 6 ft 9 in / 2,07 m *''Weight'': 5,335 lb / 2 420 kg *''Payload'': 1,750 lb / 800 kg '''WC-57''' [[File:Armistice 100 Easter Rally, 22 March, 2018 (40947748621).jpg|thumb|Contrary to the jeep, the Dodge command cars' soft-top included canvas sides ({{nobr|WC-57}} with winch).]] The WC-57 Truck, Command Reconnaissance, 3/4 ton, 4x4 w/Winch Dodge (G502) was identical to the {{nobr|WC-56}}, but fitted with a Braden MU2 7,500 lb / 3,402 kg capacity winch at the front bumper. 6,010 units built.{{sfnp|ref=SRATAM4045|Summary Report – Tank-Automotive Materiel|1945|page=63}} *''Length'': 14 ft 8 in / 4,46 m *''Width'': 6 ft 7 in / 2,00 m *''Height'': 6 ft 9 in / 2,07 m *''Weight'': 5,644 lb / 2 560 kg *''Payload'': 1,750 lb / 800 kg '''WC-58''' The WC-58 Truck, Radio, 3/4 ton, 4x4 w/o Winch, Dodge (G502) was identical to the {{nobr|WC-56}} Command / Reconnaissance Car, but fitted with a [[Signal Corps Radio]] set in front of the rear seat, and a 12-volt electrical system.{{sfnp|ref=SNL_G657|SNL G-657 Master Parts List|1943|p=XIII; 296}}[https://books.google.nl/books?id=Ljdma-SYU0gC&pg=PA60 David Doyle: Standard Catalog of U.S. Military Vehicles – 2nd Edition, pg. 60] Some {{nobr|WC-58}} models may have been built, based on the {{nobr|WC-57}} with winch, as well.[http://ftp.olive-drab.com/idphoto/id_photos_wc58.php {{nobr|WC-58}} Dodge Radio Car, 3/4 ton, 4x4 – Olive-Drab] A total of 2,344 radio equipped units were built, but it is unclear whether these were included as part of the {{nobr|WC-56}} / {{nobr|WC-57}} production, or constituted an ''additional'' 2,344 {{nobr|WC-58}} radio car units. *''Length'': 13 ft 10 in (4.22 m) / 14 ft 7 in (4.46 m) with winch *''Width'': 6 ft 7 in / 2.00 m *''Height'': 6 ft 9 in / 2.07 m *''Weight'': 5,644 lb / 2 560 kg *''Payload'': 1,750 lb / 800 kg ==={{3/4}}-ton Trucks, Weapons Carrier=== '''WC-51 and WC-52''' [[File:Verkhnyaya Pyshma Tank Museum 2011 118 (cropped).jpg|thumb|With the top and bows down, the WC-51/52 followed the low-profile design doctrine — and lack of a winch gave a better [[Approach and departure angles|approach angle]].]] [[File:Dodge WC-52.jpg|thumb|Dodge WC-52 – identical to the {{nobr|WC-51}}, but with a factory front winch.]] Almost three quarters of Dodge's 255,195 total {{3/4}}-ton G-502 WC series production, were built in the form of the {{nobr|WC-51}} and {{nobr|WC-52}}, "Truck, Cargo, {{3/4}}{{nbh}}ton, 4x4, Weapons Carrier", with or without winch. 123,541 were built without winch as the {{nobr|WC-51}}, and 59,114 with a front winch as the {{nobr|WC-52}} — for a total of 182.655 units — or just over 188,000 including the 5,380 {{nobr|WC-55s}} M6 GMC's that were later downgraded and used as {{nobr|WC-52s}}. The open cab pickup could be fitted with an optional M24A1 machine gun mount, which bolted across the front of the bed. The mount could carry the [[M1918 Browning Automatic Rifle]], the [[M1919 Browning machine gun]], or the [[M2 Browning machine gun]]. The WC-52 was identical to the {{nobr|WC-51}}, but fitted with a [[power take-off]] driven Braden MU{{nbh}}2 7,500 lb / 3,402 kg capacity winch at the front bumper. As before, the winch equipped models actually had different, longer frames than those without, so a winch wasn't easily added in the field. . *''Length'': 13 ft 11 in / 4.24 m — 14 ft 9 in / 4,48 m with winch *''Width'': 6 ft 11 in / 2.11 meters *''Height (with canvas cover)'': 6 ft 10 in / 2.08 m *''Height (with top down)'': 5 ft 2 in / 1.57 m *''Weight'': 5,250 lb / 2 382 kg net — 5,550 lb / 2 518 kg net with winch *''Payload'': 1,750 lb / 800 kg *''Tires'' 9.00 x 16 in., 8ply [[File:Stewart Air Show 2017 DSC00034 (46766705192) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Up to ten troops would fit in a WC-51 or WC-52.]] A substantial amount, and almost a quarter of all {{3/4}}-ton weapons carriers (44,229 - with or w/o winch), were provided to World War II allies, under Lend-Lease: * 24,902 to the Soviet Union * 10,884 to Great Britain * 3,711 to China * 3,495 to the free French forces * 954 to Brazil and 204 to other Latin American republics ==={{3/4}}-ton Truck, Gun Motor Carriage=== '''WC-55''' [[File:Dodge wc55 m6 37 mm GMC.jpg|thumb|WC-55 Gun Motor Carriage]] {{main|M6 Gun Motor Carriage}} The '''M6 37 mm Gun Motor Carriage (3/4-ton, 4x4)''' (or '''GMC'''), also known as '''M6 Fargo''', and by Dodge as the {{nobr|WC-55}} Truck, was a modified [[List of U.S. military vehicles by supply catalog designation#G500 to G599|'''G-502''']] Dodge {{nobr|WC-52}}, designed and built to carry an M3A1 37mm antitank gun and shield, mounted on its cargo bed. The {{nobr|WC-55}} with gun combination was designated M6 Fargo Gun Motor Carriage with 37mm Anti-tank Gun, with supply catalog Standard Nomenclature List number ([[List of U.S. military vehicles by supply catalog designation#G100 to G199|'''G-121''']]). A total of 5,380 were built by Fargo in 1942,{{sfnp|ref=SRATAM4045|Summary Report – Tank-Automotive Materiel|1945|page=19}} but most were later dismantled / downgraded and returned to service as {{nobr|WC-52}} cargo trucks. *''Length'': 14 ft 8½ in / 4,48 m *''Height'': 8 ft 2 in / 2,49 m to top of gun shield *''Weight'': 5,600 lb / 2 540 kg *''Width'': 7 ft 2 in / 2,18 m *''Payload'': 80 rounds 37mm ==={{3/4}}-ton Telephone Service=== '''WC-59''' [[File:DodgeWC-59 telephone truck.jpg|thumb|WC-59, 3/4-ton K-50 telephone truck with ladder on side.]] The WC-59 Truck, Telephone Maintenance, 3/4 ton, 4x4 Dodge (G502) was designed to install and repair telephone lines. Based on the same chassis as the {{nobr|WC-54}}, but with a wheelbase increased by 50 cm. The spare wheel was carried behind the seats, with a step ladder fitted to where the spare wheel would have been. 549 were built. The bed was known by the Signal Corps as the [[K-50 truck]], and was fitted to both Dodge and Chevrolet chassis. *''Length'': 16 ft 0 in / 4,88 m *''Height'': 6 ft 9 in / 2,06 m *''Weight'': 5,357 lb / 2 430 kg *''Width'': 6 ft 6 in / 1,98 m *''Payload'': 1,750 lb / 800 kg '''WC-61''' [[File:Dodge K-50B.jpg|thumb|WC-61 / K-50B truck]] The WC-61 Light Maintenance Truck, 3/4 ton, 4x4 Dodge (G502) was designed to install and repair telephone lines. Replacement for the {{nobr|WC-59}}, the {{nobr|WC-61}} had the step ladder fitted to the roof, the spare wheel was fitted behind the seats, and the tool trunks were accessible from the outside. 58 built. The US Signal Corps referred to these as the [[K-50B truck]]. *''Length'': 15 ft 6 in / 4,73 m *''Height (without ladder)'': 7 ft 5 in / 2,26 m *''Weight'': 5,952 lb / 2 700 kg *''Width'': 6 ft 10 in / 2,08 m *''Payload'': 1,750 lb / 800 kg ==={{3/4}}-ton Truck, Emergency Repair=== '''WC-60''' [[File:Dodge T-214 WC-60 Emergency Repair Chassis (USM-BT-22) from SNL G-657.jpg|thumb|Dodge WC-60 Emergency Repair Chassis, M2]] The WC-60 chassis, fitted with a bed similar to the {{nobr|WC-61}} by American Coach and Body Co. (Cleveland, Ohio), formed the "[[List of U.S. military vehicles by model number#Pre-consecutive trucks|M2 Emergency Repair truck]], 3/4 ton, 4x4 Dodge" ([[List of U.S. military vehicles by supply catalog designation|G-61 / G-502]]), a mobile workshop designed for field maintenance. Its open-topped service-type bed featured numerous tool trunks and stowage bins, accessible from the outside. 296 built. *''Length'': 15 ft 6 in / 4.73 m *''Height'': 7 ft 5 in / 2.26 m *''Weight'': 5,952 lb / 2 700 kg *''Width'': 6 ft 10 in / 2.08 m *''Payload'': 1,750 lb / 800 kg {{clear}} ==Descriptions — One-and-a-half-ton models== {{multiple image |direction=vertical |width=220 |header=G-507, 1{{1/2}}-ton, 6x6 trucks |image1=Dodge WC-63, Museum of Retro Cars.jpg |caption1='''WC-62''' – ''without'' winch |image2=Defilada z okazji Święta WP - 2008 (14).jpg |caption2='''WC-63''' – ''with'' winch |image3=Dodge T223 (or WC62) Weapons Carrier pic2.JPG |caption3=WC-62 / WC-63 cabin interior }} ====WC-62==== The G507 Cargo and Personnel Carrier, 1{{1/2}}-ton, 6x6 Truck, Dodge ({{nobr|WC-62}} w/o Winch) was based on a lengthened {{nobr|WC-51}} Weapons Carrier with an extra axle added. When the army enlarged rifle squads from eight to twelve men, the {{3/4}}-ton no longer sufficed, and a 48-inch longer 6x6 variant was created that used most of the mechanical parts and some of the sheet metal of the G-502. The G507 trucks could be driven by all six wheels (6x6) or by the four rear wheels only (6x4).U.S. Army Technical Manual TM9-1808B, 1943, page 4 A number of components were strengthened in this design, and many of these changes were also incorporated in subsequent {{3/4}}-ton production. Production amounted to 43,224 units total, — 23,092 {{nobr|WC-62}} units without winch, and 20,132 {{nobr|WC-63}} variants ''with'' winch.{{sfnp|ref=SRATAM4045|Summary Report – Tank-Automotive Materiel|1945|page=66}} One prototype was produced as an armored car.{{cite web|url=http://www.warwheels.net/FargoArmoredTruckINDEX.html |title=Fargo 6x6 Armored Truck Index |publisher=Warwheels.net |date= |accessdate=2013-06-06}} A total of 6,344 WC-62 and WC-63 cargo trucks were provided to World War II Allies — 4,074 to the free French forces, 2,123 to Great Britain, and 137 units to Brazil. *''Length'': 17 ft 11 in / 5.47 m *''Width'': 6 ft 11 in / 2.11 m *''Height (with canvas cover)'': 7 ft 3 in / 2.21 m *''Height (with top down)'': 5 ft 2 in / 1.57 m *''Weight'': 6,925 lb / 3 141 kg *''Payload'': 3,300 lb / 1500 kg ====WC-63==== The WC-63 Truck, Cargo and Personnel Carrier, 1{{1/2}} ton, 6x6 with Winch, Dodge (G507) ''Weapons Carrier'' was based on a lengthened {{nobr|WC-52}} with an extra axle added. Identical to the {{nobr|WC-62}} but fitted with a [[Power take-off|PTO]] powered Braden MU2 winch, initially of 5,000 pound, later 7,500 pound capacity. *''Length'': 18 ft 9 in / 5,72 m *''Width'': 6 ft 11 in / 2,10 m *''Height (with canvas cover)'': 7 ft 3 in / 2,21 m *''Height (with top down)'': 5 ft 2 in / 1,57 m *''Weight'': 7,175 lb / 3 250 kg *''Payload'': 3,300 lb / 1500 kg ==Comprehensive models table== This comprehensive, sortable table has been compiled to further elaborate and clarify the extensive range of models in the larger Dodge WC series family, the different codes that were applied, and some of each model's base characteristics, based on dodge's SNL G-657 Master Parts List, U.S. Army technical model manuals, such as the TM9-2800 (editions of 1943 and 1947) and others, the U.S. Summary Report of Tank Automotive Acceptances (!945/1946), and various additional sources. Different colors have been used to code groupings for maximum convenience, based on nominal payload rating, model family, and wheels and drive.

[[Warren, Michigan]][http://www.dodgepilothouseclub.org/know/vin/model.htm Dodge B series serial number classification] |model_years=1948-1953 |layout=[[FR layout]] |class=[[Full-size]] [[pickup truck]] |body_style=2-door [[pickup truck]] |transmission=3-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]] |successor=[[Dodge C Series]] |predecessor=[[Dodge T-, V-, W-Series]] |wheelbase={{convert|116|in|mm|abbr=on}}
{{convert|108|in|mm|abbr=on}} }} [[Dodge]] has used the '''B series''' name on two different vehicles, a [[pickup truck]] and a [[van]]. ==Pickup truck== [[File:'52 Dodge Pickup (Auto classique Salaberry-De-Valleyfield '11).jpg|thumb|left|1952 Dodge B series]] The B-series pickup trucks were sold from 1948-1953. They replaced the prewar Dodge truck and were replaced by the [[Dodge C series]] in 1954. The B-series trucks came in several different variants. The B1-B were ½ ton trucks standard with a {{convert|95|hp|kW|abbr=on}} flathead-[[straight-six engine]] while the B1-C were ¾ ton trucks with a standard {{convert|108|hp|kW|abbr=on}} flathead-straight 6 engine. It also came in several other variants such as the B1-T and B1-V which were semi-truck cabs and vans, respectively. A [[Woodie (car body style)|woodie]] version, the "Suburban", was also available from outside companies. [[File:1949 Dodge Suburban.jpg|thumb|1949 Dodge B-series woodie [[carryall]] ]] The B-series trucks featured a high-visibility "pilot-house" cab with optional rear quarter windows. The engine was shifted forward and the front axle moved back on the frame for better weight distribution as well as a shorter wheelbase, moving from {{convert|116|in|mm|abbr=on}} to {{convert|108|in|mm|abbr=on}}. The cargo bed sides were made higher to increase capacity by 40%. The redesigned cab could seat three people, with {{convert|2.5|in|mm|abbr=on}} more height, {{convert|6|in|mm|abbr=on}} more width and {{convert|3|in|mm|abbr=on}} additional in length. The cab was mounted on rubber mounts for an improved ride. Another innovation for the time was the use of cross-steering arrangement, giving the trucks a 37° turning radius. The cargo box space was increased over previous models and overload springs made optional on all variants to increase hauling capacity. In 1950, more new features were added as the 3-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]] shift lever was relocated to the steering column instead of on the floor. A fluid drive standard transmission, with 3 or 4 speeds, became an available option. The front end and dashboard/gauge layout were redesigned for 1951. 1953 was the last year of the Pilot-house, but brought many new changes. The Truck-O-Matic transmission, a fully [[automatic transmission]] was available for ½ and ¾ton models. A longer {{convert|7|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} bed became available, which would increase the wheelbase to {{convert|116|in|mm|abbr=on}}. And the new wide "step-style" rear fenders were added, which would continue to be used by Dodge up until the 1980s. ==Van== {{See also|Dodge Ram Van}} [[File:Ramvan.jpg|thumb|1996 Dodge Ram Van Wagon]] The B series also includes full-sized vans made by the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation from 1970 (as early 1971 models) through 2003. During that time, they were originally numbered B100, B200, and B300; the numbers were later upped by 50 (B150, etc.) and finally multiplied by 10 (B1500, B2500, B3500) in the mid-1990s. The actual names were Dodge Sportsman, Dodge Tradesman, Dodge Van, at first; they later changed to Ram Van, Ram Wagon, and, briefly. There was also a Kary Van extended height model. The cargo and passenger vans used the same frame and powerplants (both [[Straight-six engine|6-]] and [[V8 engine]]s), but the passenger vans had seats for up to 15 passengers (on the extended length, long-wheelbase Maxivans), dual air-conditioning systems (in later years), and large windows on both sides. The 15-passenger vans are today commonly used by military, commuters, church groups, scouts, urban camping, and some corporations. Throughout their run, two wheelbases were used: {{convert|109|in|mm|abbr=on}} and {{convert|127|in|mm|abbr=on}}, with an extended length version based on the {{convert|127|in|mm|abbr=on}} wheelbase. Engines ranged from the 198 in³ [[Chrysler Slant-6 engine|Slant Six]] (available only in 1970-71), to the 440 in³ V8 (only briefly available in the late 1970s), with factory compressed-natural-gas 318 in³ (5.2 L) engines available from around 1995 onwards, to fleet buyers only. A popular Kary Van (basically a factory-built cube van, instead of upfitted by an aftermarket company), which extended the cargo area height to {{convert|6|ft|2|in|m|abbr=on}}, was added in 1972. A sliding door was made optional in 1974; that same year, the original stamped aluminum grille was also replaced with a molded plastic part. A one-piece rear door and hard-service interior were made optional in 1975.[http://www.allpar.com/trucks/b-vans.html B-Vans/Allpar] For many years, Dodge was the sales leader for vans, including conversions for tradespeople, ambulances, school buses, and campers, working with numerous upfitters to provide alternatives for customers. However, in 1979, the RV market crashed, and Dodge stopped making RV chassis; their van sales also dropped roughly in half. After that, upgrades to the "B-vans" came more slowly, especially as the vans' utility was in some ways duplicated by the company's own popular [[Plymouth Voyager]] and [[Dodge Caravan]] minivans. In 1988, a 239 in³ (3.9 L) [[V6]] originally developed for the [[Dodge Dakota]] mid-size pickup replaced the 225 in³ (3.7 L) Slant Six, and throttle body injection was given to the 318 V8. The 360 in³ (5.9 L) V8 gaining fuel injection and a roller camshaft in 1989. In 1990, rear wheel antilock brakes were made optional, along with a heavy-duty four-speed [[automatic transmission]]. In 1992, the V6 and 5.2L V8 engines were fitted with sequential multiple-port fuel injection (SMPI) and a "barrel" / "kegger"-type intake manifold, which boosted power dramatically, and the outboard positions of the rear seat gained three-point belts. In the same year, [[compressed natural gas]] 5.2 L engines became optional for fleet buyers. The 5.9 L received the new intake and SMPI for 1993. Numerous changes to the drivetrain, body, and suspension were made after 1993, as Dodge tried to make the vans more competitive, leading to a fairly sizeable redesign in 1998, which added numerous features, made the vans more driveable and safer, and added power to the 5.9 L V8 engine. More, and also substantial, changes were made for the 2000 model year, but little was changed from then until the final vans. Dodge stopped making the vans in June 2003, citing the expense of meeting future safety standards and slow sales. The Pillette Road plant in Windsor, Ontario which made the vans was closed down and later demolished. ==References== *Bunn, Don (2003). "Dodge B-Series Trucks: Restorer's and Collector's Reference Guide and History" {{ISBN|1-58388-087-9}}. ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.allpar.com/trucks/b-vans.html B-Vans at Allpar, 1970–2003] *[http://www.pickuptrucks.com/html/history/segment6.html B-series truck info at PickupTruck.com] {{Dodge}} [[Category:Dodge vehicles|B series]] [[Category:Pickup trucks]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:1940s cars]] [[Category:1950s cars]]

2-speed automatic }} The '''C series''' was a line of [[pickup truck]]s sold by [[Dodge]] from 1954 to 1960. It replaced the [[Dodge B series]] of trucks and was eventually supplanted by the [[Dodge D series]], introduced in 1961. Unlike the B series, which were closely related to Dodge's prewar trucks, the C series was a complete redesign. Dodge continued the "pilot house" tradition of high-visibility cabs with a wraparound windshield introduced in 1955. A two-speed "[[PowerFlite]]" [[automatic transmission]] was newly available that year. Chrysler called the [[Chrysler FirePower engine|Hemi]]-powered Dodge trucks "Power Giant" in 1957, and introduced power steering and brakes, a three-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]], and a 12-volt electrical system. From 1957 to 1959, Dodge proposed the ''Sweptside pickup'', a rival to the [[Chevrolet Cameo Carrier|Chevrolet ''Cameo Carrier'']], but it never became a best-seller.{{cite web |url=http://auto.howstuffworks.com/1957-1959-dodge-d100-sweptside-pickup.htm |title=1957-1959 Dodge D100 Sweptside Pickup|publisher=HowStuffWorks |access-date=28 April 2015}} A flat-sided (and thus wider) "Sweptline" cargo box came in 1959. The company also adopted the standard pickup truck numbering scheme, also used by Ford and GM at that time. Thus, the ½ ton Dodge was now called the D100. A traditional separate-fender body "Utiline" version was also built which had a [[GVWR]] of {{convert|9000|lb|kg|abbr=on}}. Engines (light-duty): *1957-1960; ''[[Chrysler Flathead engine|Flathead]]'' [[Straight-six engine|I6]], {{convert|120|hp|kW|abbr=on}} *1959; 331 in³ ''[[Chrysler FirePower engine#331|FirePower]]'' V8, {{convert|172|hp|kW|abbr=on}} *1957-1959; 315 in³ ''[[Chrysler FirePower engine#315|Red Ram]]'' V8, {{convert|204|hp|kW|abbr=on}} *1959; 318 in³ ''[[Chrysler A engine#318|A-type]]'' V8, {{convert|200|hp|kW|abbr=on}} 1954-55 Dodge C-Series.jpg|1954–56 model 1957 Dodge Sweptside Pickup.jpg|1957 model (Sweptside pickup) 1960 Dodge Sweptline half ton (2906406858).jpg|1958–60 model ==Medium-duty/heavy-duty C series== {{Main|Dodge LCF series}} Since it still utilized the older cab design, the C series name was continued for Dodge's line of medium- and heavy-duty trucks (better known as the [[Dodge LCF Series|LCF series]]) through the 1975 model year, long after most of Dodge's other trucks had moved to the newer D series designation. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *Pickup Trucks.com **[http://www.pickuptrucks.com/html/history/segment7.html Dodge Trucks History: 1954 to 1955 C-series pickups] **[http://www.pickuptrucks.com/html/history/segment8.html Dodge Trucks History: 1957 to 1960 Power Giant pickups] *[http://auto.howstuffworks.com/1957-1959-dodge-d100-sweptside-pickup.htm 1957-1959 Dodge D100 sweptside pickup] {{Dodge}} [[Category:Dodge vehicles|C series]] [[Category:Pickup trucks]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:1960s cars]]

{{more footnotes|date=September 2018}} {{About|the first generation of the Dodge Viper sports car|general information about the car|Dodge Viper}} {{Infobox automobile | name = Dodge Viper (SR I) | image = Dodge Viper RT-10 - Flickr - Alexandre Prévot (9).jpg | production = 1991–1995 | model_years = 1992–1995 | assembly = [[New Mack Assembly]], [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], United States | designer = [[Tom Gale (designer)|Tom Gale]] (1990) | class = [[Sports car]] ([[S-segment|S]]) | body_style = 2-door [[Targa top|targa]] | engine = 8.0-liter (488.1 cu in) odd-firing ''[[Viper engine#First generation|Viper]]'' [[V10 engine|V10]] | powerout = {{convert|400|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}
{{convert|465|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} | transmission = 6-speed ''[[BorgWarner]] T56'' [[manual transmission|manual]] | wheelbase = {{convert|2440|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|4450|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|1920|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|1120|mm|in|abbr=on|1}} | weight = {{convert|1490|kg|lbs|abbr=on|0}} | successor = [[Dodge Viper (SR II)]] | layout = [[FR layout]] | manufacturer = | related = [[Rinspeed Veleno]] }} The '''Dodge Viper (SR I)''' is the first generation of the [[Dodge Viper|Viper]] [[sports car]], manufactured by American automobile manufacturer [[Dodge]]. It was originally tested in January 1989 as a prototype, then later introduced in 1991 as a pace car for the [[Indianapolis 500]], then finally going on sale in January 1992. The SR I began the Dodge Viper model lineup, which would continue on until 2017, consisting of five generations. The SRI was replaced by the updated SRII after a series of updates in 1995. == History and development == [[File:1991 Dodge Viper Indianapolis 500 Pace Car.jpg|left|thumb|220x220px|The pre-production Dodge Viper (SR I) as the pace car for the [[1991 Indianapolis 500]].]] [[File:Dodge Viper RT-10 - Flickr - Alexandre Prévot (4).jpg|left|thumb|The lightweight hard top became an option for later Viper models.]]The original Viper was intended to be a performance sports car. The project was started in 1988 at Chrysler's Advanced Design Studios, when then-president [[Bob Lutz (businessman)|Bob Lutz]] suggested to [[Tom Gale (designer)|Tom Gale]] that the company should consider the production of a modern [[AC Cobra|Cobra]]. A clay model was created months later, and the car later appeared as a concept in 1989 at the [[North American International Auto Show]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theautochannel.com/vehicles/coll/sci/112metal.html|title=The American Carrozzeria|last=Lamm|first=Michael|publisher=The Auto Channel|accessdate=May 17, 2012}} Chief engineer Roy Sjoberg was then directed to develop the car after public reactions of the initial concept were highly positive. "Team Viper" was later formed with 85 engineers selected by Sjoberg, and development of the car began in March 1989, with full completion in February 1990. It was later introduced in 1991 at [[1991 Indianapolis 500|the Indianapolis 500 of that year]] with a [[pre-production car]] driven by [[Carroll Shelby]], being forced to replace the [[Dodge Stealth]] because of complaints coming from the [[United Automobile Workers]]. It later went on sale as the ''Dodge Viper RT/10 Roadster'' in January 1992. == Engineering and design == [[File:Dodge Viper RT-10 - Flickr - Alexandre Prévot (13).jpg|thumb|200x200px|Rear view of the Viper.]] The Viper lacks modern driver aids such as [[Traction control system|traction control]] and [[anti-lock brakes]]. The car also has no exterior-mounted door handles or key locks, and instead, entry is done by unzipping a vinyl window to reach the interior door release handle (when the canvas/hard top is in place). No [[air conditioning]] was installed on the car (the option for A/C was added in later models). There were also no [[Airbag|airbags]] for weight reduction. The roof was made from [[canvas]], and the windows were made from vinyl and used zippers to open and close. Despite these lack of features, the car still had some features in order for it to be tolerable as a daily driving car, such as manually-adjustable seats with lumbar support, an AM/FM stereo player, a clock, and carpeting. Later models of the Viper allowed the option for a lightweight fiberglass hard top to replace the standard canvas soft top. [[Lamborghini]], who was owned by Chrysler Corporation at the time, assisted with the design of the aluminum-alloy [[V10 engine]] for the car, with the design based on Chrysler's [[Chrysler LA engine|LA engine]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2dRqgSuHAjgC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA296#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Car: The Definitive Visual History of the Automobile|date=2011|publisher=Penguin|isbn=9780756689384|page=296|language=en|accessdate=22 July 2018}} Dick Winkles, the chief power engineer, was a major contributor on the engine project, and had spent time in Italy for the purpose of the engine's development. == Specifications and performance == The engine generated a maximum power output of {{convert|400|hp|kW PS|abbr=on|0}} at 4,600 rpm and {{convert|465|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} and 3,600 rpm, and weighed {{Convert|323|kg|lbs|0|abbr=on}}. Fuel economy rated by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] to be {{convert|12|mpgus|abbr=on}} during city driving and {{convert|20|mpgus|abbr=on}} on the highway, all made possible due to long gearing.{{cite web|url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/compx2008f.jsp?hiddenField=Manufacturer&year=1994&make=Dodge|title=Vehicle Table|date=September 10, 2006|publisher=Fueleconomy.gov|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090103053726/http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/compx2008f.jsp?hiddenField=Manufacturer&year=1994&make=Dodge|archivedate=January 3, 2009|url-status=dead|accessdate=September 29, 2010}} The Dodge Viper has a curb weight of {{convert|1490|kg|lbs|0|abbr=on}}, with the body's tubular steel frame and [[resin-transfer molding]] [[fiberglass]] panels. The car is able to accelerate from {{convert|0-60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in 4.6 seconds, {{convert|0-100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in 9.2 seconds, completes a quarter mile (402 m) in 12.6 seconds at the speed of {{cvt|113.8|mph|kph|1|abbr=on}} and has a maximum speed of {{convert|165|mph|km/h|0|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.vipercentral.com/specifications/|title=Dodge Viper (1992-1994) Specifications|accessdate=7 May 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vipercentral.com/specifications/|title=Dodge Viper (1992-1994) Specifications|accessdate=7 May 2018}} Its large tires allowed the car to average 0.96 lateral ''g'' in corners, which placed it among the best performance cars of its day, however, the car proved tricky for the unskilled drivers.{{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/insideline/do/Features/articleId=119146|title=A history of the Dodge Viper from concept to current generation|publisher=Edmunds.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913235433/http://www.edmunds.com/insideline/do/Features/articleId%3D119146|archivedate=September 13, 2008|url-status=dead|accessdate=September 29, 2010|df=mdy-all}} == Gallery == File:DODGE Viper Gen 1.JPG|Front view (open top) File:Dodge Viper RT-10 - Flickr - Alexandre Prévot (4).jpg|Front view (hard top) File:Dodge Viper RT-10 - Flickr - Alexandre Prévot (13).jpg|Rear view (open top) File:Dodge Viper RT-10 - Flickr - Alexandre Prévot (7).jpg|Rear view (hard top) File:1992 Dodge Viper interior.JPG|Interior File:1992 Dodge Viper engine.JPG|8.0-liter V10 engine == References == {{Reflist}}{{Dodge timeline 1980 to date}} [[Category:Dodge vehicles]] [[Category:Sports cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1992]]

[[Fiat Ulysse]] }} The '''Dodge Journey''' is a [[Mid-size car|mid-size]] [[crossover (automobile)|crossover SUV]] manufactured and marketed by [[FCA US LLC]]'s [[Dodge]] brand since [[model year]] 2009, with a minor [[Facelift (automotive)|facelift]] for the 2011 model year. With styling by [[Ryan Nagode]],{{cite web | title = DRIVELINE: Dodge has strong hand in Journey | publisher = The London Free Press, Harry Pegg, February 8, 2008 | url = http://lfpress.ca/perl-bin/publish.cgi?x=articles&p=224188&s=wheels}} the Journey was marketed globally in both [[Right- and left-hand traffic|left and right hand drive]]. In many markets it was also sold as the '''Fiat Freemont'''. ==Overview== The Dodge Journey debuted at the 2007 [[Frankfurt Motor Show]],{{cite web|last=Neff |first=John |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2007/08/26/2009-dodge-journey-crossover-will-debut-in-frankfurt/ |title=2009 Dodge Journey crossover will debut in Frankfurt |publisher=Autoblog.com |date=2007-08-26 |accessdate=2010-10-10}}{{cite web|last=Neff |first=John |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2007/09/11/frankfurt-2007-dodge-journey-drops-in-germany/ |title=Frankfurt 2007: Dodge Journey drops in Germany |publisher=Autoblog.com |date=2007-11-09 |accessdate=2010-10-10}} later appearing at the 2009 [[Frankfurt Motor Show]].{{cite web |url=http://blog.chryslerllc.com/entry/758/a_walking_tour_of_chryslers_stand_at_frankfurt |title=A Walking Tour of Chrysler's Stand at Frankfurt |publisher=Blog.chryslerllc.com |accessdate=2010-10-10 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708152450/http://blog.chryslerllc.com/entry/758/a_walking_tour_of_chryslers_stand_at_frankfurt |archivedate=2011-07-08 }} Identified internally as the '''JC49''',http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/suvs/112_0804_2009_dodge_journey_first_drive/specifications.html the Journey shares a modified [[automobile platform|platform]] with the [[Dodge Avenger]] and an identical wheelbase to the outgoing short wheel base (SWB) Chrysler minivan, a slightly shorter wheelbase {{convert|113.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} than the outgoing [[Chrysler Pacifica]]. Featuring 5- or 7-passenger seating with four forward-hinged doors, the Journey is available with a [[Straight-4|four-cylinder engine]], as with past models of the Chrysler SWB minivans. Production versions of 2009 model year vehicles went on sale in 2008 for the 2009 model-year in [[North America]], and mid-2008 elsewhere. A version for the [[People's Republic of China|Chinese]] market was unveiled at Auto China in 2008, marketed as the JCUV. Initial model production began in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcarfans.com/9080422.005/dodge-journey-launched-in-china-as-jcuv|title=Dodge Journey Launched in China as JCUV|date=2008-04-22|accessdate=2009-05-27|author=Frank de Leeuw van Weenen}} Freemont went on sale in Russia in 2013.{{cite web |url=http://wroom.ru/en/news/663 |title=Fiat Freemont Minivan Soon on Sale in Russia |author= |date=4 June 2013 |website=Wroom.ru |accessdate=21 October 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021131946/http://wroom.ru/en/news/663 |archive-date=21 October 2013 |url-status=dead }} Halfway through the 2009 model year, the model name emblem moved to the right-end of the trunk lid, replaced by the brand emblem. {{clear left}} ===2011 update=== Revisions for the 2011 model-year include modifications to the grille, lower front fascia, redesigned interior, suspension, steering, powertrain, and use of Dodge's new logo, launched in 2011, as well as LED Taillights.[http://blog.caranddriver.com/2011-dodge-journey-receives-face-lift-pentastar-v6-revised-interior/ 2011 Dodge Journey receives facelift, Pentastar V6 & revised interior.] -- ''[[Car & Driver]]'' (Retrieved October 21, 2010) For the 2012 model year, the Journey became Dodge's smallest SUV after FCA stopped manufacturing the [[Dodge Nitro|Nitro]]. For the 2013 model year, Dodge released the Journey Blacktop, with 19-inch gloss black aluminum wheels and center caps, a gloss black grille, gloss black bezel headlamps, gloss black lower front fascia accent and gloss black exterior mirrors. In 2014, the Journey Crossroad was introduced with chrome accents along the lower part of the body and in the interior, a large bumper, smoked head- and taillights, a black grille, rocker panels, rails for a roof rack, and a skid plate simile at the rear.{{cite web | url = http://www.autoevolution.com/reviews/dodge-journey-review-2015.html | title = 2015 Dodge Journey Review | last = Ross | first = Jeffrey | work = autoevolution | publisher = SoftNews NET | date = 2015-03-15 }} Chrysler added the revised Dodge logo with two slanted rectangles for the 2013 Model Year. For the 2016 model-year, the Journey's AVP and Limited trims were discontinued and the Crossroad Plus trim was added and also for the 2017 model-year, the R/T trim is replaced by the GT trim.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} '''Pre-facelift styling''' File:2010 Dodge Journey RT CRD 2.0 Front.jpg|Front File:2010 Dodge Journey RT CRD 2.0 Rear.jpg|Rear '''Post-facelift styling''' Freemont=== [[File:2013 Fiat Freemont (JF) Lounge wagon (2015-06-08) 01.jpg|thumb|left|Fiat Freemont]] Chrysler [[badge engineering|rebadged]] the [[Mexico]]-manufactured[http://www.autoweek.com/article/20101227/CARNEWS/101229933 Fiat will rebadge Dodge Journey in Europe] -- [[Autoweek]] (Retrieved December 27, 2010 Journey in [[Europe]] after model year 2011 as the '''Fiat Freemont''', unveiled at the [[Geneva Motor Show#2011|2011 Geneva Motor Show]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.italiaspeed.com/2011/cars/fiat/01/freemont/2401.html|title=24.01.2011 FIRST LOOK AT GENEVA BOUND FIAT BADGED DODGE JOURNEY CROSSOVER|accessdate=2011-01-24|work=italiaspeed.com}} and began marketing the [[Dodge Durango|Durango]]. The Freemont had its Italian launch in the end of May 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://europeancarnews.com/2011/06/01/fiat-says-the-freemonts-launch-was-a-success/#more-337|title=Fiat says the Freemont’s launch was a success.|accessdate=2011-06-01|work=europeancarnews.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815213612/http://europeancarnews.com/2011/06/01/fiat-says-the-freemonts-launch-was-a-success/#more-337|archive-date=2011-08-15|url-status=dead}} It has two front-wheel-drive turbodiesel variants the {{Convert|140|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} and the {{Convert|170|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} version of Fiat's 2.0 L Multijet turbodiesel. Later will be introduced all-wheel-drive version of {{Convert|170|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} diesel and the Pentastar V6.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fiatpress.com/index.php?lng=2&group=1&method=cartelle&action=zoom&id=4963|title=Fiat Freemont, international debut|accessdate=2011-01-25|work=fiatpress.com}} In [[Australia]], [[Brazil]] and [[China]], both the Freemont and the Journey are available for sale. However, to create a distinct market for the two vehicles, the Freemont is only available with the 2.0 and 2.4L 4-cylinder engines in the market other than China, while the Journey is now only sold with the Pentastar V6 engine (both engines were available before the launch of the Freemont). The Freemont was originally available in [[Right- and left-hand traffic|LHD]] markets only, except [[the Netherlands]]. ''Fiat Group Automobiles Netherlands'' did not offer the Fiat Freemont on the Dutch market, owing to the Dutch [[tax]] climate, that would make the car too expensive to become a sales success.{{citation needed|date=February 2020}} However, a RHD model was introduced to [[Australia]], but not in the [[United Kingdom]]. In January 2011, ''[[What Car?]]'' expressed doubts for the model to reach the United Kingdom.{{cite web|title=Fiat Freemont seven-seater unveiled|url=http://www.whatcar.com/car-news/fiat-freemont-seven-seater-unveiled/1199023|publisher=whatcar.com|date=January 24, 2011|accessdate=May 12, 2015}} ===2020 model year changes=== For the 2020 [[model year]], the Dodge Journey will be offered in two trim levels: SE Value and Crossroad. All other trim levels (SE and GT) have been discontinued. All 2020 Journey models will be powered by the same 2.4L inline four-cylinder (I4) engine, mated to the 4-speed automatic transmission, and front wheel drive (FWD). The 3.6L [[Pentastar]] V6 engine, 6-speed automatic transmission, and all wheel drive (AWD) have all been discontinued for 2020. A Blacktop Package becomes available on the SE Plus trim that adds 17-inch gloss black-finished aluminum alloy wheels and black-painted exterior accents. The SE Value trim also gains standard seven-passenger seating with a third-row split-folding bench seat. The Crossroad also gains additional standard equipment, such as a power sunroof. All trims receive standard rear park assist and rearview backup camera, and a Popular Equipment Group is now available on both trims for 2020.{{cite web|url=https://media.fcanorthamerica.com/newsrelease.do?id=20872&mid=183|accessdate=13 November 2019|date=1 September 2019|title=2020 Dodge Journey Fact Sheet}} ===Engines=== The available [[Inline-four engine|four-cylinder]] is a {{convert|2.4|L|cuin|0|abbr=on}}, with {{convert|173|hp|abbr=on}} and {{convert|166|lb·ft|N.m|abbr=on}} of torque; a version of Chrysler's [[Global Engine Manufacturing Alliance|GEMA]] built, [[World Gasoline Engine|World Engine]] class of four-cylinder engines shared with Hyundai and Mitsubishi.{{cite web |url=http://www.media.chrysler.com/dcxms/assets/specs/2009_DodgeJourneySpecifications_WN.pdf |title=2009 Journey |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-09-26 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708152824/http://www.media.chrysler.com/dcxms/assets/specs/2009_DodgeJourneySpecifications_WN.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-08 }}{{cite web | title = 2009 Dodge Journey Road Test | url = http://www.thecarconnection.com/Vehicle_Reviews/SUVs_Wagons/2009_Dodge_Journey_Road_Test.S181.A13859.html?pg=3 |publisher=Carconnection.com, Marty Padgett, February 1, 2008}} [[File:Journey Interior.jpg|thumb|left|Dodge Journey interior (2009-2010)]] [[File:Interni Fiat Freemont2.JPG|thumb|right|Fiat Freemont interior]] Through 2010, the [[V6]] offered in North America was a {{convert|3.5|L|cuin|0|abbr=on}} with a six-speed automatic transmission, producing {{convert|235|hp|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|232|lb·ft|N.m|abbr=on}} of torque. For 2011, it was changed to the 3.6-liter [[Pentastar]] V6, producing {{convert|283|hp|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|260|lb·ft|N.m|abbr=on}} torque.{{Cite web|url=http://media.chrysler.com/newsrelease.do;jsessionid=698AE0C1FAA5CBE9F36D0E15880CE74C?&mid=2&id=10140|title=2011 Dodge Journey Crosses Over: A Gorgeous New Spirit and a Driver’s Soul|accessdate=2010-12-28|work=media.chrysler.com/newsrelease}} Other markets offer the six-speed [[automatic transmission]] with the flex-fuel ([[E85]] compatible) 2.7-liter V6. All-wheel drive is only available with a V6. Also through 2010 a [[Volkswagen Group|Volkswagen]]-sourced diesel engine was available outside of North America with an automatically shifted [[dual clutch transmission]]. Chrysler performed primary engineering for the dual-clutch transmission with support from long-time partner Getrag, which was to build the transmission in the United States. Due to funding issues, this did not happen, and the factory, nearly finished, was sold and used for other purposes.[http://www.allpar.com/news/index.php/2011/01/chrysler-getrag-contractors-partly-paid Chrysler-Getrag contractors: partly paid]. ''allpar.com''.
